When [[Cramer-Krasselt]] took over as Master Lock's agency later in the year, the company decided to make the gun ads a tradition, and began to produce new ads themed around the concept (including one featuring skeptics of previous editions of the ad, and one showcasing the company's major corporate clients) for future Super Bowls during the subsequent decades (aside from a brief hiatus in 1986 and 1987), and the early 1990s. Allen went as far as describing the ads as an "event" that continued to attract media attention after the game. The Super Bowl ads helped improve Master Lock's market share; from 1973 through 1994, sales had increased from $35 million per year to $200 million per year. Master Lock's yearly Super Bowl commercials accounted for nearly all of the company's annual advertising budget.<ref name=milwaukee-lock>{{cite web|title=Master Lock's famous commercial helps maintain lock on the market|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fpZQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EhMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4191,4036051&dq=master+lock+super+bowl+ad&hl=en|work=The Milwaukee Sentinel|date=March 14, 1994|accessdate=February 3, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906143734/https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fpZQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EhMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4191,4036051&dq=master+lock+super+bowl+ad&hl=en|archive-date=September 6, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=usatoday-masterlock>{{Cite web|title=Revisiting the classic Master Lock ad from 1974|url=http://admeter.usatoday.com/2015/01/09/revisiting-the-classic-master-lock-ad-from-1974/|accessdate=March 20, 2015|work=USA Today|date=January 9, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402093606/http://admeter.usatoday.com/2015/01/09/revisiting-the-classic-master-lock-ad-from-1974/|archive-date=April 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Master Lock article|journal=Brill's Content|date=1999|volume=2|issue=1-5|publisher=Brill Media Ventures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=33liAAAAMAAJ&q=master+lock+super+bowl+budget&dq=master+lock+super+bowl+budget&hl=en&sa=X&ei=9hATVauJL82wsATj2YHYBg&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBDgK|accessdate=March 25, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Ambler|first1=Tim|title=The Financial Times Guide to Marketing : from advertising to zen|date=1996|publisher=Pitman Pub.|location=London|isbn=0273620320}}</ref>
=== Coca-Cola === At [[Super Bowl XIV]] in 1980, [[Coca-Cola]] aired an advertisement popularly known as "[[Hey Kid, Catch!]]", featuring [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] [[All-Pro]] defensive lineman [[Joe Greene (American football)|"Mean Joe" Greene]] being offered a Coca-Cola by a young fan—played by Tommy Okon,<ref name=ew-joegreene/> drinking it in one sip, and tossing the kid his game-worn jersey as repayment. The advertisement was filmed in 1979 and premiered that October, but did not gain mainstream attention until its airing during Super Bowl XIV. "Hey Kid, Catch!" became one of Greene's most famous roles; the ad would win a [[Clio Award]], spawn a [[made-for-TV movie]] on NBC entitled ''The Steeler and the Pittsburgh Kid'', and be re-made for other markets with local athletes. In a 2011 poll by ''[[Advertising Age]]'', readers named "Hey Kid, Catch!" as the best Super Bowl commercial of all-time.<ref name=usatoday-heykid>{{Cite web|title='Hey kid, catch!' Mean Joe Greene, Coca-Cola and the greatest Super Bowl ad of all time|url=http://admeter.usatoday.com/2015/01/05/hey-kid-catch-mean-joe-greene-coca-cola-and-the-greatest-super-bowl-ad-of-all-time/|website=USA Today|accessdate=March 20, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402142513/http://admeter.usatoday.com/2015/01/05/hey-kid-catch-mean-joe-greene-coca-cola-and-the-greatest-super-bowl-ad-of-all-time/|archive-date=April 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The ad also became the subject of parodies on television series, such as ''[[The Simpsons]]'', and in other ads. At [[Super Bowl XLIII]] in 2009, Coca-Cola aired a parody of the ad for its [[Coca-Cola Zero]] brand starring Steelers [[Safety (American and Canadian football position)|safety]] [[Troy Polamalu]]. Continuing an ongoing theme in the promotion of Coke Zero, the ad was interrupted by a Coca-Cola "brand manager" accusing Polamalu of "stealing" their commercial; in response, Polamalu tackled him and ripped off his shirt to give to the child.<ref name=freep-09ads>{{cite web|last1=Hinds|first1=Julie|title=Super Bowl ads deliver big laughs|url=http://archive.freep.com/article/20090202/ENT03/902020367/Super-Bowl-ads-deliver-big-laughs|website=Detroit Free Press|accessdate=March 20, 2015|date=February 2, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402133105/http://archive.freep.com/article/20090202/ENT03/902020367/Super-Bowl-ads-deliver-big-laughs|archive-date=April 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=abchron-meanjoezero>{{Cite web|title=Coke to reprise ‘Mean Joe’ commercial for Super Bowl|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2009/01/26/daily11.html|website=Atlanta Business Chronicle|accessdate=March 20, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402172150/http://www.bizjournals.com/atlanta/stories/2009/01/26/daily11.html|archive-date=April 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2012, [[Procter & Gamble]] aired a parody of the ad entitled "Stinky". The ad saw Greene reprise his role, but having the young fan throw [[Downy]] Unstoppables [[fabric softener]] to Greene instead of Coca-Cola, and the fan rejecting his jersey because it smelled.<ref name=Adweek-stinky>{{cite web |title=Coke's Classic Super Bowl Ad Gets 'Stinky' |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/cokes-classic-super-bowl-ad-gets-stinky-137882 |work=[[Adweek]] |first=Andrew |last=McMains |date=January 31, 2012 |access-date=February 3, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930103517/http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/cokes-classic-super-bowl-ad-gets-stinky-137882 |archive-date=September 30, 2012 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 2016, Joe Greene was reunited with Okon as part of a segment for CBS's ''Super Bowl's Greatest Commercials'' special.<ref name=ew-joegreene>{{Cite web|title='Mean' Joe Greene reunites with Coca-Cola kid nearly 40 years after iconic Super Bowl ad|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/01/27/mean-joe-greene-coca-cola-super-bowl-ad|accessdate=January 28, 2016|work=Entertainment Weekly|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160130230056/http://www.ew.com/article/2016/01/27/mean-joe-greene-coca-cola-super-bowl-ad|archive-date=January 30, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Coca-Cola has also used the Super Bowl for other campaigns: in 2009, the company aired new ads as part of its recently introduced [[Open Happiness]] campaign.<ref name=abchron-meanjoezero/> In 2014, the company aired the [[multiculturalism]]-themed ad "It's Beautiful", which featured scenes of Americans of [[Race and ethnicity in the United States|various races and ethnicities]], including the first ever [[same-sex couple]] featured in a Super Bowl commercial. However, the ad attracted [[#Coca-Cola: "It's Beautiful"|controversy]] due to its use of a multilingual rendition of "[[America the Beautiful]]" as its soundtrack.<ref name="time-cocacolaad">{{Cite web |title=Coca Cola's "It's Beautiful" Super Bowl Ad Brings Out Some Ugly Americans |url=http://entertainment.time.com/2014/02/02/coca-colas-its-beautiful-super-bowl-ad-brings-out-some-ugly-americans/ |work=[[Time.com]] |publisher=[[Time Inc.|Time]] |date=February 2, 2014 |first=James |last=Poniewozik |access-date=February 4, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203222554/http://entertainment.time.com/2014/02/02/coca-colas-its-beautiful-super-bowl-ad-brings-out-some-ugly-americans/ |archive-date=February 3, 2014 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=independent-cocacolaad/> In 2015, the company aired ad entitled "#makeithappy"; themed around [[cyberbullying]], the ad featured negative comments directed towards a teen being transformed into positive messages after a technician accidentally spills a bottle of Coca-Cola on a server.<ref name=lat-makeithappy>{{Cite web|title=Coca Cola #makeithappy Super Bowl ad calls on stopping Internet negativity|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-coca-cola-make-it-happy-super-bowl-ad-20150201-story.html|accessdate=March 20, 2015|work=Los Angeles Times|date=February 1, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150226193044/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-coca-cola-make-it-happy-super-bowl-ad-20150201-story.html|archive-date=February 26, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Macintosh: "1984"=== {{main|1984 (advertisement)}} [[File:Macintosh 128k transparency.png|thumb|upright|"1984", an ad for the [[Macintosh 128K|Macintosh]] computer (pictured), has been widely considered the best Super Bowl ad of all-time.]] At [[Super Bowl XVIII]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple Computer]] broadcast an advertisement for its [[Macintosh 128K|Macintosh computer]] entitled "1984", created by the agency [[Chiat/Day]] and directed by [[Ridley Scott]]. The advertisement, which incorporated elements inspired by the novel ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]'', featured a woman wearing track-and-field clothing (including orange pants and a white shirt branded with an image of the Macintosh) sprinting into a large auditorium and hurling a large hammer into a screen (displaying a large [[Big Brother (Nineteen Eighty-Four)|Big Brother]]-like figure speaking to a massive assembly of drone-like people in the audience), concluding with the message "On January 24, Apple Computer will introduce the Macintosh. And you'll see why 1984 won’t be like '1984.'" The advertisement received critical acclaim from both viewers and critics alike for helping position the Macintosh as a unique entry into the [[personal computer]] market, and is often considered to be one of the best Super Bowl advertisements of all-time.<ref name=Adweek-1984goodasitgets>{{cite web |last1=Hayden |first1=Steve |title='1984': As Good as It Gets |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/1984-good-it-gets-125608 |website=[[Adweek]] |date=January 30, 2011 |access-date=January 21, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121183238/http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/1984-good-it-gets-125608 |archive-date=January 21, 2015 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=forbes-1984>{{Cite web|title=Experts and Viewers Agree: Apple's '1984' Is The Best Super Bowl Ad Of All Time|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jacquelynsmith/2012/01/30/experts-and-viewers-agree-apples-1984-is-the-best-super-bowl-ad-of-all-time/|work=Forbes|accessdate=February 3, 2013|first=Jacquelyn|last=Smith|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130206012848/http://www.forbes.com/sites/jacquelynsmith/2012/01/30/experts-and-viewers-agree-apples-1984-is-the-best-super-bowl-ad-of-all-time/|archive-date=February 6, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.duke.edu/~tlove/mac.htm | title= Apple's 1984: The Introduction of the Macintosh in the Cultural History of Personal Computers | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/19991005015117/http://www.duke.edu/~tlove/mac.htm | archivedate= October 5, 1999 | first= Ted | last= Friedman | date= October 1997 | deadurl= yes | df= mdy-all }}</ref>
The ad first aired nationally during Super Bowl XVIII. As the agency wanted "1984" to be eligible for that year's industry awards, which were only open to ads that aired during 1983, a low-profile premiere of the ad occurred on the [[Twin Falls, Idaho]] station [[KMVT]] on December 31, 1983 shortly before midnight.<ref name=mentalfloss-1984>{{cite web|title=The True Story of Apple's "1984" Ad's First Broadcast...Before the Super Bowl|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/29911/true-story-apples-1984-ads-first-broadcastbefore-super-bowl|work=Mental Floss|accessdate=January 18, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140107034201/http://mentalfloss.com/article/29911/true-story-apples-1984-ads-first-broadcastbefore-super-bowl|archive-date=January 7, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Apple attempted to follow up "1984" the following year with a new ad entitled "[[Lemmings (advertisement)|Lemmings]]", to promote its [[Macintosh Office]] system. The ad, which featured blindfolded businessmen walking over the edge of a cliff in unison, was criticized for its "dark" theme and exaggerated premise. By contrast, "Lemmings" has been considered to be one of Apple's worst television advertisements.<ref name=forbes-appleworst>{{Cite web|title=Apple's Worst Ads – Before The Unfortunate 'Genius'|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jacquelynsmith/2012/08/03/apples-worst-ads-before-the-unfortunate-genius/|work=Forbes|accessdate=February 3, 2013|first=Jacquelyn|last=Smith|date=August 3, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110115649/http://www.forbes.com/sites/jacquelynsmith/2012/08/03/apples-worst-ads-before-the-unfortunate-genius/|archive-date=November 10, 2012|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Budweiser=== The [[beer]] brand [[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Budweiser]] has long been a Super Bowl fixture. Its parent company [[Anheuser-Busch]] held a long-term contract with the NFL that allowed it to buy several slots of air time from the game's broadcaster each year at a steep discount, a contract that ran through [[Super Bowl 50]];<ref name="sbj-5m">Ourand, John (February 3, 2015). “[http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2015/02/02/Media/SuperBowlAds.aspx CBS price for Super Bowl 50 spot: $5M?] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204032822/http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2015/02/02/Media/SuperBowlAds.aspx |date=February 4, 2015 }}” ''Sports Business Journal''. Retrieved February 3, 2015.</ref> the company continues to buy multiple commercials in each game.<ref name=no_clydesdales>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/budweiser-benches-famous-clydesdales-for-super-bowl-lii-1516975201|title=Budweiser benches famous Clydesdales for Super Bowl LII|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=January 27, 2018|accessdate=January 27, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180127015522/https://www.wsj.com/articles/budweiser-benches-famous-clydesdales-for-super-bowl-lii-1516975201|archive-date=January 27, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Budweiser runs several advertising campaigns throughout each game, one of which has traditionally featured its mascots, the [[Budweiser Clydesdales]].<ref name=mp-busch2013>{{cite web|title=Bud Scores A Touchdown With Baby Clydesdale|url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/192615/bud-scores-a-touchdown-with-baby-clydesdale.html|work=MediaPost|accessdate=February 6, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130207225621/http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/192615/bud-scores-a-touchdown-with-baby-clydesdale.html|archive-date=February 7, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The Clydesdales were included in at least one Super Bowl commercial every year from [[Super Bowl IX]] in 1975 through [[Super Bowl LI]] in 2017.<ref name=no_clydesdales/> Budweiser's parent company [[Anheuser-Busch]] has been the most successful advertiser in the annual [[USA Today Super Bowl Ad Meter|Super Bowl Ad Meter]] survey organized by ''[[USA Today]]'', having finished first on the survey fourteen times.<ref name=usatoday-admeter2014/><ref name=usatoday-bud2013/> When ''USA Today'' held an "All-Time Ad Meter" [[bracket tournament]] in 2014, two Budweiser commercials met in the finals; the winner was a 2008 ad spoofing ''[[Rocky]]'', which went against its 1999 ad "Separated at Birth", which featured a pair of [[Dalmatian (dog)|Dalmatian]] puppies given to two separate owners, but eventually seeing each other again after one became a mascot dog on the Clydesdales' carriage.<ref name=usa-alltimewinner>{{Cite web|title=The Ad Meter bracket champ: Budweiser's 2008 Clydesdale commercial|url=http://admeter.usatoday.com/story/sports/ad-meter/super-bowl/all-time-lists/2014/01/31/ad-meter-story-bracket-champion-budweiser-2008/5088819/|work=USA Today|accessdate=February 5, 2014|first1=Glenn|last1=Davis|date=January 31, 2014|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140205174047/http://admeter.usatoday.com/story/sports/ad-meter/super-bowl/all-time-lists/2014/01/31/ad-meter-story-bracket-champion-budweiser-2008/5088819/|archive-date=February 5, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
As of 2015, Budweiser had won the survey thirteen times in fifteen years; its 2013 advertisement entitled "Brotherhood" focused on the relationship and emotional reunion of a [[Clydesdale horse|clydesdale]] with its original trainer three years after leaving to become a Budweiser Clydesdale.<ref name=usatoday-bud2013>{{Cite web|title=Budweiser's Clydesdale wins Ad Meter by a nose|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/02/04/clydesdale-ad-wins-by-a-nose/1889693/|work=USA Today|accessdate=February 6, 2013|first1=Bruce|last1=Horovitz|date=February 4, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130206023126/http://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/02/04/clydesdale-ad-wins-by-a-nose/1889693/|archive-date=February 6, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=adage-2013>{{cite web|title=Super Bowl Poll of Polls: A Clear Ad Winner Emerges|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/ad-age-s-dashboard-super-bowl-ad-results/239585/|work=Advertising Age|accessdate=February 6, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203072601/http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/ad-age-s-dashboard-super-bowl-ad-results/239585/|archive-date=February 3, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Prior to the game, Budweiser also invited users to vote via [[Twitter]] on a name for the new [[foal]] that would be featured in the ad.<ref name=mp-busch2013/> A 2014 ad entitled "Puppy Love" featured a similar reunion between an adopted [[dog]] and another Budweiser Clydesdale.<ref name=usatoday-admeter2014>{{Cite web|title='Puppy Love': 2014 Ad Meter winner|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/02/02/ad-meter-winner-story/5087939/|work=USA Today|accessdate=February 4, 2014|first1=Bruce|last1=Horovitz|date=February 2, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204062229/http://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/02/02/ad-meter-winner-story/5087939/|archive-date=February 4, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Its most recent victory and its third in a row, 2015's "Lost Dog", featured a dog being rescued from a wolf by the Clydesdales.<ref name=usatoday-admeter2015>{{Cite web|title=Budweiser 'Lost Dog' finds way to top of Super Bowl Ad Meter|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2015/02/01/usa-today-ad-meter-2015-super-bowl-money/22378605/|website=USA Today|publisher=Gannett|accessdate=February 3, 2015|date=February 1, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203000801/http://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2015/02/01/usa-today-ad-meter-2015-super-bowl-money/22378605/|archive-date=February 3, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2017, Budweiser broadcast "Born the Hard Way", an ad which dramatized Anheuser-Busch co-founder [[Adolphus Busch]]'s emigration to the United States from Germany to establish the company. The advertisement attracted controversy among supporters of U.S. president [[Donald Trump]] for being pro-immigration, in the wake of an [[Executive Order 13769|executive order]] issued by Trump which briefly restricted entry into the country by residents of several countries with predominant [[Muslim]] populations. A boycott effort also emerged among Trump supporters.<ref name=budimmigration>{{cite web|last=Godoy|first=Maria|title=Budweiser's Super Bowl Ad And The Great Debate Over What It Means To Be An American|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/03/513263766/budweiser-s-super-bowl-ad-misses-the-real-timelier-story-about-immigrants-and-be|accessdate=February 4, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170203232713/http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/02/03/513263766/budweiser-s-super-bowl-ad-misses-the-real-timelier-story-about-immigrants-and-be|archive-date=February 3, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="trib-bud17">{{cite web|title=Donald Trump supporters call for Budweiser boycott over pro-immigration ad|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-trump-supporters-budweiser-boycott-20170206-story.html|website=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=6 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206193600/http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-trump-supporters-budweiser-boycott-20170206-story.html|archive-date=February 6, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=A Boycott Budweiser movement begins over Super Bowl immigration ad|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/02/04/a-boycott-budweiser-movement-begins-over-super-bowl-immigration-ad/|website=Washington Post|accessdate=6 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206155812/https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2017/02/04/a-boycott-budweiser-movement-begins-over-super-bowl-immigration-ad/|archive-date=February 6, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Anheuser-Busch denied that the ad was meant to be a political message, as it had been in production for the past year, and that it was meant to "highlight the ambition of our founder, Adolphus Busch, and his unrelenting pursuit of the American dream."<ref name="trib-bud17"/> Barring a brief appearance, the Clydesdales were not prominently featured during the ad. However, Budweiser's social media outlets promoted "ClydesdaleCam", a [[Facebook]] live stream of the Clydesdales watching the game in a stable and waiting to see their cameo.<ref name="usatoday-noclydesdales">{{cite web|title=Where were Budweiser's Clydesdales during the Super Bowl?|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ad-meter/2017/02/06/where-were-budweisers-clydesdales-during-super-bowl/97548828/|website=USA Today|accessdate=6 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170209132634/http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ad-meter/2017/02/06/where-were-budweisers-clydesdales-during-super-bowl/97548828/|archive-date=February 9, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/budweisers-clydesdale-cam-airs-live-on-facebook-during-super-bowl/|title=Budweiser's 'Clydesdale Cam' Airs Live on Facebook During Super Bowl|work=Adweek|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207005208/http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/budweisers-clydesdale-cam-airs-live-on-facebook-during-super-bowl/|archive-date=February 7, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2018, Budweiser broadcast "Stand by You", an ad which chronicled Anheuser-Busch's [[disaster relief]] program of distributing cans of [[drinking water]] from its brewery in [[Cartersville, Georgia]]. The Clydesdales were, once again, downplayed from its television spots, with the brewery only airing a 5-second bumper in the second quarter to promote its streaming ClydesdaleCam event.<ref name="no_clydesdales"/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2018/01/26/budweiser-2018-super-bowl-commercial-video/|title=Budweiser's New Super Bowl Has Nothing to Do With Beer|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180204175925/http://fortune.com/2018/01/26/budweiser-2018-super-bowl-commercial-video/|archive-date=February 4, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> However, the Clydesdales were featured in several digital-oriented companion campaigns alongside the game, including ClydesdaleCam, a second, web-exclusive ad entitled "Beer Country", as well as themed [[Snapchat]] filters.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/how-the-budweiser-clydesdales-will-make-an-appearance-during-the-super-bowl/|title=How the Budweiser Clydesdales Will Make an Appearance During the Super Bowl|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207011003/http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/how-the-budweiser-clydesdales-will-make-an-appearance-during-the-super-bowl/|archive-date=February 7, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Budweiser has introduced other campaigns during the Super Bowl as well. During [[Super Bowl XXIII]], Budweiser aired an episodic series of commercials known as the ''[[Bud Bowl]]''—which featured a football game between [[stop motion]]-animated beer bottles representing Budweiser and [[Bud Light]], with commentary by [[Bob Costas]] and [[Paul Maguire]]. Proving popular, the ''Bud Bowl'' would return at subsequent Super Bowls; it had become so popular that some viewers actually [[Sports betting|wagered]] on the outcome of the ''Bud Bowl'' as if it were an actual event.<ref name=variety-11ads>{{Cite web|last1=Stienberg|first1=Brian|title=Super Bowl Ads: 11 Commercials That Forced The Big Game To Change Its Spots|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/news/super-bowl-ads-11-commercials-that-forced-the-big-game-to-change-its-spots-1201415196/|website=Variety|accessdate=March 21, 2015|date=January 26, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150324100122/http://variety.com/2015/tv/news/super-bowl-ads-11-commercials-that-forced-the-big-game-to-change-its-spots-1201415196/|archive-date=March 24, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=trib-budbowl>{{Cite web|title=Bud Bowl-king Of Ads For The King Of Beers|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1991-11-17/business/9104140117_1_beer-bottle-computer-animation-super-bowl|accessdate=March 21, 2015|work=Chicago Tribune|date=November 17, 1991|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402123817/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1991-11-17/business/9104140117_1_beer-bottle-computer-animation-super-bowl|archive-date=April 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=ds-budbowl>{{cite web|title=Not-So-Secret Origin Of The Bud Bowl, Including Surprise, Alternate Ending|url=http://deadspin.com/5139483/not+so+secret-origin-of-the-bud-bowl-including-surprise-alternate-ending?autoplay=true|work=Deadspin|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]|accessdate=February 6, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222001541/http://deadspin.com/5139483/not+so+secret-origin-of-the-bud-bowl-including-surprise-alternate-ending?autoplay=true|archive-date=February 22, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 1995, Budweiser introduced the first of a series of ads featuring a group of three [[Budweiser Frogs|frogs]] named Bud, Weis, and Er. The frog ads were a major success for the brewery after the game, and ranked as one of its most popular advertising campaigns following its premiere.<ref name=usatoday-frogs>{{Cite web|title=Budweiser frogs enchant viewers|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/index/ad010.htm|work=USA Today|accessdate=February 6, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130305102620/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/index/ad010.htm|archive-date=March 5, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Anheuser-Busch has aired commercials for other beer brands during the game alongside Budweiser, such as Budweiser Black Crown, and [[Beck's Brewery|Beck's Sapphire]].<ref name=mp-busch2013/> At Super Bowl LI, the company re-launched [[Busch beer|Busch]],<ref name="ftu-busch2017">{{cite web|title=First-ever Busch beer Super Bowl ad a nod to the brand’s past — and glimpse of its future|url=http://jacksonville.com/entertainment/2017-02-01/first-ever-busch-beer-super-bowl-ad-nod-brand-s-past-and-glimpse-its-future|website=Florida Times-Union|accessdate=7 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170208035114/http://jacksonville.com/entertainment/2017-02-01/first-ever-busch-beer-super-bowl-ad-nod-brand-s-past-and-glimpse-its-future|archive-date=February 8, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=See the 'Buschhhhh' Super Bowl Ad|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/buschhhhh-super-bowl-ad/307777/|website=Advertising Age|accessdate=7 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206163859/http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/buschhhhh-super-bowl-ad/307777/|archive-date=February 6, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and broadcast a Bud Light ad featuring the ghost of its former dog mascot [[Spuds MacKenzie]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Kate|title=Bud Light is bringing back a controversial mascot who once helped sales soar 20%|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/bud-light-spuds-mackenzie-super-bowl-ad-2017-2|work=Business Insider|date=February 2, 2017|language=en|access-date=February 9, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170205075808/http://www.businessinsider.com/bud-light-spuds-mackenzie-super-bowl-ad-2017-2|archive-date=February 5, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="people-dogredux">{{cite web|title=Super Bowl Dog Redux: Explaining Spuds MacKenzie to Millennial and Gen Z Audiences|url=http://people.com/pets/super-bowl-dog-redux-explaining-spuds-mackenzie-to-younger-audiences/|website=People|accessdate=8 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211080131/http://people.com/pets/super-bowl-dog-redux-explaining-spuds-mackenzie-to-younger-audiences/|archive-date=February 11, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== Chrysler === [[Chrysler]], and the marques of its current parent company [[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles]], have made repeated appearances during the Super Bowl. From 2011 through 2014, Chrysler became known for running several notable long-form ads;<ref name="variety-timerunningout">{{cite web|title=At Super Bowl, Has Time Run Out for Two-Minute Commercials?|url=https://variety.com/2017/tv/news/super-bowl-commercials-two-minute-tv-advertising-1201973928/|website=Variety|accessdate=6 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180206011626/http://variety.com/2017/tv/news/super-bowl-commercials-two-minute-tv-advertising-1201973928/|archive-date=February 6, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> at [[Super Bowl XLV]], Chrysler aired a two-minute long ad entitled "[[Born of Fire]]" to launch the [[Chrysler 200]] and the company's new slogan "Imported from Detroit". The ad featured scenes depicting the history and revitalization of [[Detroit]], as well as local rapper [[Eminem]] and his song "[[Lose Yourself]]". The ad was critically acclaimed, and won a [[63rd Primetime Creative Arts Emmy Awards|Creative Arts Emmy Award]] for "Best Commercial" in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |author=Mark Memmott |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2011/02/08/133592299/eminems-imported-from-detroit-super-bowl-ad-for-chrysler-scores-big |title=Eminem's 'Imported from Detroit' Super Bowl Ad For Chrysler Scores Big : The Two-Way |publisher=NPR |date=2011-02-08 |accessdate=2016-02-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029065528/http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2011/02/08/133592299/eminems-imported-from-detroit-super-bowl-ad-for-chrysler-scores-big |archive-date=October 29, 2017 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Tetzeli |first=Rick |url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1724789/super-bowl-ad-stories-chrysler-eminem-break-awkward-silence-detroit |title=Super Bowl Ad Stories: Chrysler, Eminem Break an Awkward Silence in Detroit |website=Fast Company |date=2011-02-07 |accessdate=2016-02-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170207114426/https://www.fastcompany.com/1724789/super-bowl-ad-stories-chrysler-eminem-break-awkward-silence-detroit |archive-date=February 7, 2017 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Ashley C. Woods |url=http://www.mlive.com/tv/index.ssf/2011/12/born_of_fire_chrysler_200_ad_s.html |title='Born of Fire' Chrysler 200 ad featuring Eminem was simply the best of 2011 |website=MLive.com |date=2011-12-23 |accessdate=2016-02-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170814141413/http://www.mlive.com/tv/index.ssf/2011/12/born_of_fire_chrysler_200_ad_s.html |archive-date=August 14, 2017 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
During [[Super Bowl XLVI]], Chrysler broadcast "Halftime in America", a two-minute long commercial directed by [[David Gordon Green]], written by poet [[Matthew Dickman]] and narrated by actor [[Clint Eastwood]]. The commercial recounted the [[automotive industry crisis of 2008–10]], set to scenes showing Americans in despair, but then in hope. The narration of the ad equated the emergence from the crisis to the second half of a football game, explaining that "All that matters now is what’s ahead: how do we come from behind? How do we come together? And how do we win? Detroit’s showing us it can be done. And what’s true about them is true about all of us. This country can’t be knocked out with one punch. We get right back up again, and when we do the world’s gonna hear the roar of our engines." The ad was heavily viewed online after the game, receiving over 4 million views on [[YouTube]] within 36 hours, but also attracted [[#Chrysler: "Halftime in America"|controversy]] due to its political overtones.<ref name=time-halftimeinamerica>{{Cite web |last1=Corliss |first1=Richard |title=Clint’s Halftime Ad: From the Director of Pineapple Express |url=http://entertainment.time.com/2012/02/07/clints-chrysler-ad-from-the-director-of-pineapple-express/ |website=[[Time.com]] |publisher=[[Time Inc.|Time]] |date=February 7, 2012 |access-date=March 25, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402091337/http://entertainment.time.com/2012/02/07/clints-chrysler-ad-from-the-director-of-pineapple-express/ |archive-date=April 2, 2015 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
[[Super Bowl XLVII]] featured an ad for [[Ram Trucks]], which adapted [[Paul Harvey]]'s 1978 speech "[[So God Made a Farmer]]." During [[Super Bowl 50]], the company focused exclusively on its SUV brand [[Jeep]]. At [[Super Bowl LI]], the company similarly focused exclusively on [[Alfa Romeo]], as part of a campaign to re-launch the Fiat-owned brand in the United States.<ref name="adage-alfaromeo">{{cite web|title=What Is Fiat Chrysler Up to for the Super Bowl?|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/fiat-chrysler-back-super-bowl/307839/|website=Advertising Age|accessdate=6 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206184556/http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/fiat-chrysler-back-super-bowl/307839/|archive-date=February 6, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="adage-avoidpolitics">{{cite web|title=Fiat Chrysler Avoids Politics in Super Bowl Ads, Plugs Alfa Romeo|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/super-bowl-fiat-chrysler-avoids-politics-plugs-alfa-romeo/307861/|website=Advertising Age|accessdate=6 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206074753/http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/super-bowl-fiat-chrysler-avoids-politics-plugs-alfa-romeo/307861/|archive-date=February 6, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[Super Bowl LII]] featured two Ram Trucks commercials, the latter featuring an extract from a 1968 speech by [[Martin Luther King Jr.]], as well as three Jeep ads.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/creativity/jeep-runs-3-very-different-super-bowl-ads-created-by-3-different-agencies/|title=Jeep Runs 3 Very Different Super Bowl Ads Created by 3 Different Agencies|work=Adweek|access-date=2018-02-07|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207063318/http://www.adweek.com/creativity/jeep-runs-3-very-different-super-bowl-ads-created-by-3-different-agencies/|archive-date=February 7, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== The Dot-com Super Bowl === {{main|Dot-com commercials during Super Bowl XXXIV}} [[Super Bowl XXXIV]] (2000) became notable for featuring a large number of commercials from [[dot-com company|dot-com companies]], to the extent that critics dubbed it the "Dot-com Super Bowl".<ref name="Comp1">Shroeder, Charlie. [http://weekendamerica.publicradio.org/display/web/2008/01/31/superbowlad/ "The Dot-Com Super Bowl"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203174011/http://weekendamerica.publicradio.org/display/web/2008/01/31/superbowlad/ |date=February 3, 2016 }}, ''[[Weekend America]]'', February 2, 2008. Accessed February 26, 2014.</ref> With a 30-second ad costing around $2.2 million, 20% of the commercial time sold went to dot-com companies—constituting $44 million of the $130 million spent in total on Super Bowl advertising time that year. Despite their aspirations and the boosts in traffic they received from the ads, all of the publicly held companies which advertised saw their stocks slump after the game as the [[dot-com bubble]] began to rapidly deflate. Some of the companies that advertised during the game—including [[Epidemic Marketing]] and [[Pets.com]], had become defunct by the end of the year, and at [[Super Bowl XXXV]], only three dot-com companies—[[E-Trade]], [[HotJobs]], and [[Monster.com]]—advertised during the game.<ref name=sfchron-dotcomsuperbowl>{{Cite web|title=Dot-Com Super Bowl Advertisers Fumble / But Down Under, LifeMinders.com may win at Olympics|url=http://www.sfgate.com/business/networth/article/Dot-Com-Super-Bowl-Advertisers-Fumble-But-Down-2739134.php|accessdate=March 18, 2015|work=San Francisco Chronicle|first=Kathleen|last=Pender|date=September 13, 2000|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201190730/http://www.sfgate.com/business/networth/article/Dot-Com-Super-Bowl-Advertisers-Fumble-But-Down-2739134.php|archive-date=February 1, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="bloom">Hyman, Mark, and Tom Lowry. [http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2001-01-07/whats-missing-from-super-bowl-xxxv "What's Missing from Super Bowl XXXV?"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402183346/http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2001-01-07/whats-missing-from-super-bowl-xxxv |date=April 2, 2015 }}, ''[[Businessweek]]'', January 7, 2001. Accessed February 28, 2014.</ref>
Notable dot-com ads broadcast during the game included "If You Leave Me Now", an ad for Pets.com which introduced the website's iconic sock puppet mascot, a self-proclaimed "worst commercial on the Super Bowl" by LifeMinder.com that consisted only of text captions on a yellow background with "[[Chopsticks (song)|Chopsticks]]" playing in the background, and "Monkey"—a deliberately nonsensical E-Trade ad that featured a monkey dancing to "[[La Cucaracha]]", and the tagline "Well, we just wasted $2,000,000. What are you doing with your money?"<ref name=time-19bestmonkey>{{Cite web |title=The 19 Best Super Bowl Ads of All Time |url=http://business.time.com/2014/01/29/the-19-best-super-bowl-ads-of-all-time/slide/monkey-2000-e-trade/ |website=[[Time.com]] |publisher=[[Time Inc.|Time]] |date=January 29, 2014 |first=Noah |last=Rayman |access-date=March 18, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161225032614/http://business.time.com/2014/01/29/the-19-best-super-bowl-ads-of-all-time/slide/monkey-2000-e-trade/ |archive-date=December 25, 2016 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=usatoday-5best2000>{{Cite web|title=Watch 5 of the best Super Bowl commercials from 2000|url=http://admeter.usatoday.com/2015/01/21/best-super-bowl-commercials-2000-budweiser-mountain-dew/|website=USA Today|accessdate=March 18, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402123302/http://admeter.usatoday.com/2015/01/21/best-super-bowl-commercials-2000-budweiser-mountain-dew/|archive-date=April 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=cnet-petscom>{{cite web|title=Pets.com gives a blast from the dot bomb past|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/pets-com-gives-a-blast-from-the-dot-bomb-past/|website=CNET|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=March 18, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402125231/http://www.cnet.com/news/pets-com-gives-a-blast-from-the-dot-bomb-past/|archive-date=April 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[Electronic Data Systems]] also aired an ad during the game that featured [[cowboy]]s who herded cats instead of cows.<ref name=variety-11ads />
=== Doritos === In 2006, [[Doritos]] began holding a promotion known as ''[[Crash the Super Bowl]]'', soliciting viewers to film their own Doritos commercials to possibly be aired during the game. At [[Super Bowl XLIII]] in 2009, an additional bonus prize of $1 million was added if any of the winning entries were named #1 on the Super Bowl Ad Meter survey results; Doritos would reach the #1 spot on the survey that year with an ad entitled "Free Doritos", created by Joe and Dave Herbert of [[Batesville, Indiana|Batesville]], [[Indiana]]. The ad featured an office worker attempting to fulfill a prediction that he would receive free Doritos by smashing open a [[vending machine]] with a [[crystal ball]].<ref name=nyt-diy/>
The following year, additional prizes of $600,000 and $400,000 were added for reaching second and third place on the poll, plus an additional $1 million bonus for each if three of the ads were to sweep the top three. A 2010 finalist, "UnderDog", reached second place on the poll.<ref name=nyt-diy>{{Cite web |title=Do-It-Yourself Super Ads |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/09/business/media/09adco.html |work=[[NYTimes.com]] |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] |first=Stuart |last=Elliott |date=February 9, 2010 |access-date=February 25, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100217050431/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/09/business/media/09adco.html |archive-date=February 17, 2010 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=usatoday-twonobodies>{{Cite web|title='Two nobodies from nowhere' craft winning Super Bowl ad|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/advertising/admeter/2009admeter.htm|work=USA Today|accessdate=January 17, 2014|first=Bruce|last=Horovitz|date=December 31, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131220021743/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/advertising/admeter/2009admeter.htm|archive-date=December 20, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=usatoday-doritosadmeter>{{Cite web|title=Doritos ad contest raises the stakes; winners could earn $5M|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/advertising/2009-09-09-ad-contest-doritos_n.htm|work=USA Today|accessdate=January 17, 2014|first=Bruce|last=Horovitz|date=September 10, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203014115/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/advertising/2009-09-09-ad-contest-doritos_N.htm|archive-date=December 3, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Another user-submitted Doritos ad, "The Cowboy Kid", finished in second place on the Ad Meter survey in 2014, winning $50,000. The contest itself was won by "Time Machine"; created by Ryan Thomas Andersen of [[Arizona]] and produced on a budget of only $300, the ad featured his son [[Confidence trick|scamming]] his neighbor into giving him his bag of Doritos by claiming that he had built a [[Time travel|time machine]] that was fueled by them. For winning the contest, Anderson received $1 million and an opportunity to work on set during the production of the film ''[[Avengers: Age of Ultron]]''.<ref name=usatoday-admeter2014 /><ref name=usatoday-timemachine>{{Cite web|last1=Cordova|first1=Randy|title=Ariz. man wins $1M Doritos Super Bowl ad prize|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/02/03/arizona-man-wins-doritos-super-bowl-ad-contest/5185059/|accessdate=March 21, 2015|work=The Arizona Republic|date=February 3, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302022330/http://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2014/02/03/arizona-man-wins-doritos-super-bowl-ad-contest/5185059/|archive-date=March 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===GoDaddy=== The [[Domain name registrar|domain registrar]] and [[web hosting]] company [[GoDaddy]] was well known for producing Super Bowl commercials featuring female spokespersons it dubbed "GoDaddy Girls", such as professional driver [[Danica Patrick]], and for its 2011 ad, comedian [[Joan Rivers]].<ref name=adage-godaddybumpy/> Many of the company's planned Super Bowl ads were allegedly rejected by broadcasters due to their risqué subject matter, leading to GoDaddy instead airing a "teaser" ad during the game that instructed viewers to watch the uncensored version of the ad on their website.<ref name=adage-godaddybumpy/>
The company's first appearance at [[Super Bowl XXXIX]] parodied the "[[Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy|wardrobe malfunction]]" that had occurred at last year's halftime show,<ref name=Adweek-nomoresleaze/> featuring a woman testifying to [[United States Congress|Congress]] about why GoDaddy wanted to advertise during the game, but a strap of her [[tank top]] coming undone. The ad was scheduled to air twice, but its second airing was pulled in response to concerns by Fox and the NFL over its content. The following year at [[Super Bowl XL]], thirteen ad concepts were rejected by [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] due to their content.<ref name=adage-godaddybumpy>{{cite web|last1=Stienberg|first1=Brian|title=GoDaddy Taking a Less Bumpy Road to Super Bowl Ads|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/godaddy-taking-a-bumpy-road-super-bowl-ads/231439/|website=Advertising Age|accessdate=April 6, 2015|date=December 8, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150228105209/http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/godaddy-taking-a-bumpy-road-super-bowl-ads/231439/|archive-date=February 28, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=ft-godaddy>{{cite web |last1=Calkins |first1=Tim |author2=Rucker |title=Case study: GoDaddy and the Super Bowl |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/9ff5a8ba-347d-11e0-9ebc-00144feabdc0.html |accessdate=April 6, 2015 |work=[[Financial Times]] |date=February 9, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402002643/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/9ff5a8ba-347d-11e0-9ebc-00144feabdc0.html |archive-date=April 2, 2015 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 2008, a GoDaddy ad entitled "Exposure" was rejected by Fox for using the word "[[beaver]]" as a [[double entendre]]. In turn, the ad was replaced with one advertising the availability of the ad on GoDaddy's website, attracting two million visits.<ref name=adage-godaddyexposure>{{cite web|last1=Hampp|first1=Andrew|title=GoDaddy Super Bowl Spot Sets Web-Traffic Record|url=http://adage.com/article/digital/godaddy-super-bowl-spot-sets-web-traffic-record/124846/|accessdate=April 6, 2015|work=Advertising Age|date=February 4, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203082021/http://adage.com/article/digital/godaddy-super-bowl-spot-sets-web-traffic-record/124846/|archive-date=February 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In October 2013, GoDaddy's chief marketing officer Barb Rechterman announced that the company would no longer air provocative ads during the Super Bowl, explaining that "our new brand of Super Bowl commercials will make it crystal clear what we do and who we stand for. We may be changing our approach, but as we've always said, we don't care what the critics think. We are all about our customers."<ref name=Adweek-nomoresleaze>{{cite web |last1=Nudd |first1=Tim |title=Go Daddy Promises No More Sleazy Super Bowl Ads |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/go-daddy-promises-no-more-sleazy-super-bowl-ads-153518 |website=[[Adweek]] |date=October 31, 2013 |access-date=April 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150311193021/http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/go-daddy-promises-no-more-sleazy-super-bowl-ads-153518 |archive-date=March 11, 2015 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
GoDaddy's ad in 2015, "Journey Home", was controversial for different reasons: it featured a puppy travelling back to its owner after falling out of a pickup truck, only to learn that he had been sold to a new owner using a website built with GoDaddy. The ad was criticized by animal rights groups, who felt that it implied an endorsement of commercial [[puppy mill]]s. GoDaddy quickly pulled the ad in response to the controversy; GoDaddy CEO [[Blake Irving]] explained that the ad's humor had "clearly missed the mark". [[PETA]] partially praised the ad for portraying the seller as being a "callous jerk", but explained that "The sale of animals online and from pet stores and breeders should be roundly condemned, and it was today. GoDaddy did the right thing by swiftly promoting adoption."<ref name=Adweek-puppymill>{{cite web |last1=Monollos |first1=Kristina |title=GoDaddy Pulls Super Bowl Ad After Complaints About 'Puppy Mill' Humor |url=http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/godaddy-pulls-super-bowl-ad-after-complaints-about-puppy-mill-humor-162590 |work=[[Adweek]] |date=January 27, 2015 |access-date=April 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405083518/http://www.adweek.com/news/advertising-branding/godaddy-pulls-super-bowl-ad-after-complaints-about-puppy-mill-humor-162590 |archive-date=April 5, 2015 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=slate-godaddypuppy>{{cite web |last1=Alison |first1=Griswold |title=Apparently Puppies Aren’t Always a Safe Bet in Super Bowl Ads |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/moneybox/2015/01/28/budweiser_lost_dog_and_godaddy_journey_home_super_bowl_ads_love_puppies.html |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |publisher=[[The Slate Group]] |date=January 28, 2015 |access-date=April 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402084455/http://www.slate.com/blogs/moneybox/2015/01/28/budweiser_lost_dog_and_godaddy_journey_home_super_bowl_ads_love_puppies.html |archive-date=April 2, 2015 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=== "Small Business Big Game" === As a byproduct of the increased cost of ad time at the Super Bowl, financial software company [[Intuit]] made its debut at [[Super Bowl XLVIII]] by hosting a promotion known as "Small Business Big Game", in which [[small business]]es with "inspiring" stories competed for a chance to earn a commercial during the Super Bowl funded by Intuit, as decided by user votes. Company CEO [[Brad D. Smith]] explained that the promotion was an extension of the company's goals to improve financial lives "in a way that you'd never imagine going back", while Ken Wach, senior vice president of marketing for Intuit's Small Business Group, explained that "normally you're looking at Budweiser ads or Chevy ads, so this was about putting small businesses on the national stage and shining the spotlight on them as heroes of the economy."<ref name="wsj-sbbg"/>
The winner of the 2014 edition was [[GoldieBlox]], a toy company with a focus on promoting [[mechanical engineering]] to young girls.<ref name="wsj-sbbg">{{Cite web|last1=Tadnea|first1=Nathalie|title=How Intuit Refined Its ‘Small Business Big Game’ Super Bowl Strategy|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/how-intuit-refined-its-small-business-big-game-super-bowl-strategy-1448037331|accessdate=February 3, 2016|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=November 20, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202050746/http://www.wsj.com/articles/how-intuit-refined-its-small-business-big-game-super-bowl-strategy-1448037331|archive-date=February 2, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> While the campaign was a success for the winner, resulting in increased prominence and sales, Wach felt that Intuit was not able to "sustain the momentum as much as we would have liked". At [[Super Bowl XLIX]], Intuit did not hold the promotion, but still aired an ad for its own [[TurboTax]] product.<ref name="wsj-sbbg"/> The contest returned in 2015 for [[Super Bowl 50]], and was won by [[Death Wish Coffee]].<ref name="chicagotrib-deathwishcoffee">{{cite web|title=A coffee named Death Wish wins a Super Bowl commercial Michael Brown|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-death-wish-coffee-super-bowl-commercial-20160128-story.html|website=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=February 3, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203122257/http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/ct-death-wish-coffee-super-bowl-commercial-20160128-story.html|archive-date=February 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="fastco-goldieblox">{{cite web|title=Intuit Awards GoldieBlox an Ad Spot in the Big Game|url=http://www.fastcocreate.com/3025879/super-bowl-xlviii/intuit-awards-goldieblox-an-ad-spot-in-the-big-game|website=Fast Company|accessdate=February 3, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160123165410/http://www.fastcocreate.com/3025879/super-bowl-xlviii/intuit-awards-goldieblox-an-ad-spot-in-the-big-game|archive-date=January 23, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== "I'm going to Disney World!" === [[Disney Parks]] is known for an advertising campaign associated with the Super Bowl entitled "What's Next?", but more popularly known as "[[I'm going to Disney World!]]". The ads feature a player from the winning team (typically the [[Super Bowl MVP|MVP]]) responding with the eponymous declaration after being asked what they would do after the game. These ads typically premiere on the day after the Super Bowl. The series began following [[Super Bowl XXI]], and first featured [[Phil Simms]] of the [[New York Giants]]. Disney has reportedly offered players $30,000 if they participate in the commercial and visit a Disney theme park (usually [[Disney World]] or [[Disneyland]]) afterward, and has extended the campaign to champion players in other sports. At [[Super Bowl XL]], Disney aired an in-game commercial themed around the campaign, featuring [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] and [[Seattle Seahawks]] players rehearsing the line in case they won.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06038/651246-66.stm|title=Ward's MVP performance in Super Bowl XL puts him in special class|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|access-date=2018-02-07|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110522154405/http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/06038/651246-66.stm|archive-date=May 22, 2011|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/sports/different-fortunes-for-two-champions-giants-have-a-quiet-off-season.html,%20https://www.nytimes.com/1987/07/12/sports/different-fortunes-for-two-champions-giants-have-a-quiet-off-season.html?pagewanted=all|title=Different Fortunes for Two Champions; GIANTS HAVE A QUIET OFF SEASON|last=Litsky|first=Frank|date=1987-07-12|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-07|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/26/sports/super-bowl-xxxii-notebook-not-going-to-disneyland.html|title=SUPER BOWL XXXII: NOTEBOOK; Not Going to Disneyland|last=Jolly|first=Tom|date=1998|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-07|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208004353/http://www.nytimes.com/1998/01/26/sports/super-bowl-xxxii-notebook-not-going-to-disneyland.html|archive-date=February 8, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
== Local advertising during the Super Bowl == <!-- Only add examples that have been covered by notable _national_ sources. --> In order to dodge the high costs of obtaining national ad time, or to broadcast more regionalized campaigns, some advertisers elect to purchase local advertising time from the individual network affiliates airing the Super Bowl, such as the [[Church of Scientology]]—who bought local ad time in major urban markets such as [[New York City]] in 2014, and the [[Bank of Montreal]] to promote its [[BMO Harris Bank]] branches.<ref name=gandm-bbad /><ref name=slate-scientology>{{cite web |title=Watch That Creepy Scientology Ad From the Super Bowl |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2014/02/02/scientology_super_bowl_ad_2014_watch_the_tv_spot_for_the_religion_that_aired.html |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |publisher=[[The Slate Group]] |date=February 2, 2014 |first=Jeffrey |last=Bloomer |access-date=February 3, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203223149/http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2014/02/02/scientology_super_bowl_ad_2014_watch_the_tv_spot_for_the_religion_that_aired.html |archive-date=February 3, 2014 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In 2012, [[Old Milwaukee]] broadcast a Super Bowl ad starring [[Will Ferrell]]; as an extension of the beer's regional campaign with the actor, the ad only aired in the city of [[North Platte, Nebraska]].<ref name=Adweek-milwaukee>{{cite web|title=Old Milwaukee Airs Will Ferrell Super Bowl Ad in North Platte, Neb.|url=http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/old-milwaukee-airs-will-ferrell-super-bowl-ad-north-platte-neb-138074|work=[[Adweek]]|accessdate=February 3, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221162215/http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/old-milwaukee-airs-will-ferrell-super-bowl-ad-north-platte-neb-138074|archive-date=February 21, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2014, several notable local ads were broadcast. The [[Utah Department of Transportation]] used the game to broadcast a [[public service announcement]] on [[seat belt]] usage for its ''Zero Fatalities'' campaign, which featured a depiction of a child who had died in a [[rollover]] crash because he did not use a seat belt.<ref name=Adweek-bleakest>{{cite web |title=The Year's Bleakest Super Bowl Ad Ran in Utah, and Is Tough to Watch |url=http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/years-bleakest-super-bowl-ad-ran-utah-and-tough-watch-155447 |work=[[Adweek]] |first=David |last=Griner |date=February 3, 2014 |access-date=February 3, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204010938/http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/years-bleakest-super-bowl-ad-ran-utah-and-tough-watch-155447 |archive-date=February 4, 2014 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> In [[Savannah, Georgia]], local [[personal injury lawyer]] Jamie Casino broadcast a two-minute long advertisement on [[WTGS]], which featured a [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]]-styled retelling of how he stopped [[criminal defence lawyer|representing "cold-hearted villains"]] to avenge the 2012 [[Labor Day]] shooting death of his brother Michael Biancosino, and Emily Pickels, after a subsequent statement by former police chief Willie Lovett who claimed that there were "no innocent victims", culminating with Casino digging through a grave with a [[sledgehammer]].<ref name=rollingstone-jamiecasino>{{cite web|title=Georgia Lawyer Jamie Casino Turns His Local Super Bowl Ad Into Revenge Fantasy|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/videos/georgia-lawyer-turns-local-super-bowl-ad-into-revenge-fantasy-20140203|work=Rolling Stone|accessdate=February 3, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203221356/http://www.rollingstone.com/culture/videos/georgia-lawyer-turns-local-super-bowl-ad-into-revenge-fantasy-20140203|archive-date=February 3, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The commercial went viral after the game, with ''[[The Independent]]'' dubbing it the "most metal" Super Bowl ad imaginable.<ref name=independent-jamiecasino>{{Cite web|title=Local lawyer Jamie Casino delivered the most metal Super Bowl advert imaginable|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/local-lawyer-jamie-casino-delivered-the-most-metal-super-bowl-advert-imaginable-9106084.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=February 5, 2014|location=London|first=Christopher|last=Hooton|date=February 4, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[Tribune Broadcasting]] used local time on the Fox affiliates it owned to air an extended promo for ''[[Salem (TV series)|Salem]]'', a then-upcoming series on sister cable network [[WGN America]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Tribune To Promo WGN Show On Its Fox Affils|url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/73749/tribune-to-promo-wgn-show-on-its-fox-affils|website=TVNewsCheck|publisher=NewsCheck Media|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=February 1, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2015, [[Newcastle Brown Ale]] bought time on local NBC stations to air an ad that, as a commentary on the high cost of national Super Bowl advertising time, contained plugs for 37 other products and companies it had recruited in a [[crowdfunding]] campaign.<ref name=nyt-bandofbrands>{{Cite web |title=Newcastle Brown Ale Calls for Other Brands to Join a Sly Super Bowl Ad Campaign |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/12/business/media/newcastle-brown-ale-calls-for-other-brands-to-join-a-sly-super-bowl-ad-campaign.html?_r=0 |work=[[NYTimes.com]] |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] |date=January 12, 2015 |first=Emily |last=Steel |access-date=February 25, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160609180849/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/12/business/media/newcastle-brown-ale-calls-for-other-brands-to-join-a-sly-super-bowl-ad-campaign.html?_r=0 |archive-date=June 9, 2016 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=guardian-newcastle>{{cite web|title=Newcastle Brown Ale gets meta for Super Bowl ad spot|url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2015/jan/28/newcastle-brown-ale-gets-meta-for-super-bowl-ad-spot|website=The Guardian|accessdate=February 3,
