2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In Savannah, Georgia, Jamie Casino aired a sequel to his 2014 ad that focused on the "bullies" that he had encountered throughout his life.<ref name=Adweek-casino2015>{{cite web |title=Georgia Lawyer Storms the Super Bowl Again With Another Completely Insane Local Ad |url=http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/georgia-lawyer-storms-super-bowl-again-another-completely-insane-ad-162729 |website=[[Adweek]] |first=Tim |last=Nudd |date=February 2, 2015 |access-date=February 3, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203082329/http://www.adweek.com/adfreak/georgia-lawyer-storms-super-bowl-again-another-completely-insane-ad-162729 |archive-date=February 3, 2015 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In 2016, St. Louis attorney Terry Crouppen aired a local ad in which he criticized [[Stan Kroenke]] for his decision to re-locate the [[St. Louis Rams]] to [[Los Angeles Rams|Los Angeles]].<ref name="fox-stlouisad">{{cite web|title=St. Louis fan makes Super Bowl ad slamming Stan Kroenke for moving Rams|url=http://www.foxsports.com/nfl/story/st-louis-rams-fan-super-bowl-ad-rips-stan-kroenke-moving-los-angeles-legal-advice-020616|website=FoxSports.com|accessdate=February 8, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313235849/http://www.foxsports.com/nfl/story/st-louis-rams-fan-super-bowl-ad-rips-stan-kroenke-moving-los-angeles-legal-advice-020616|archive-date=March 13, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=STL lawyer Terry Crouppen slams Stan Kroenke during Super Bowl|url=http://www.stltoday.com/lifestyles/columns/joe-holleman/lawyer-terry-crouppen-plans-to-slam-stan-during-super-bowl/article_b59423da-31b5-5d05-89aa-ddd0d5f23d44.html|accessdate=February 8, 2016|work=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=February 8, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160207222245/http://www.stltoday.com/lifestyles/columns/joe-holleman/lawyer-terry-crouppen-plans-to-slam-stan-during-super-bowl/article_b59423da-31b5-5d05-89aa-ddd0d5f23d44.html|archive-date=February 7, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2017, some Canadian companies bought local advertising time from Fox affiliates carried in the country, taking advantage of a new [[#Canadian_simsub_ban.2C_dispute|regulatory policy]] that made the Super Bowl available directly from U.S. stations via local television providers for the first time.<ref name="gandm-willfight">{{cite web|title=Bell will fight CRTC ad policy after Super Bowl ratings drop|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bells-super-bowl-ratings-drop-39-per-cent-as-ad-policy-takes-effect/article33919635/|website=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=8 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170621034739/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bells-super-bowl-ratings-drop-39-per-cent-as-ad-policy-takes-effect/article33919635/|archive-date=June 21, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 2018, rock musician [[Alice Cooper]] appeared in a local ad for [[Desert Financial Credit Union]], which played upon his [[Alice Cooper (band)|band]]'s song "[[School's Out (song)|School's Out]]" to promote its re-branding from Desert Schools Federal Credit Union.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ultimateclassicrock.com/alice-cooper-super-bowl-ad-2018/|title=Watch Alice Cooper's Super Bowl Ad|website=Ultimate Classic Rock|publisher=Townsquare Media|access-date=2018-02-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207063058/http://ultimateclassicrock.com/alice-cooper-super-bowl-ad-2018/|archive-date=February 7, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/news/2018/02/04/watch-desert-financial-s-super-bowl-commercial.html|title=https://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/news/2018/02/04/watch-desert-financial-s-super-bowl-commercial.html|website=Phoenix Business Journal|access-date=2018-02-07}}</ref> Jamie Casino also returned with a new ad.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.law.com/dailyreportonline/sites/dailyreportonline/2018/02/05/sledgehammer-swinging-lawyer-strikes-again-in-new-superbowl-ad/?slreturn=20180106190411|title=Sledgehammer-Swinging Lawyer Strikes Again in New Super Bowl Ad|work=Law.com|access-date=2018-02-07|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207122214/https://www.law.com/dailyreportonline/sites/dailyreportonline/2018/02/05/sledgehammer-swinging-lawyer-strikes-again-in-new-superbowl-ad/?slreturn=20180106190411|archive-date=February 7, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A local [[Subaru]] dealer in [[Muskegon, Michigan]] ran a simplistic ad containing only of the logos of the dealership, and the message "Congratulations [[New England Patriots|Patriots]]!", despite the fact that the [[Super Bowl LII|game]] was won by the [[Philadelphia Eagles]]. The dealership admitted that the ad was a "last minute calculated risk" and based on odds favoring the team.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/creativity/this-car-dealers-super-bowl-ad-congratulating-the-wrong-team-was-no-accident/|title=This Car Dealer's Super Bowl Ad Congratulating the Wrong Team Was No Accident|work=Adweek|access-date=2018-02-07|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207022007/http://www.adweek.com/creativity/this-car-dealers-super-bowl-ad-congratulating-the-wrong-team-was-no-accident/|archive-date=February 7, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Controversial Super Bowl commercials== A number of Super Bowl commercials have been considered controversial by viewers and critics, or even outright blocked by networks' [[Standards and Practices]] departments, because of concerns surrounding their contents. [[Political advertising]] and most direct forms of issue-related advertising are usually not aired during the Super Bowl because of [[equal-time rule]]s or other factors,<ref>Teinowitz, Ira. [http://www.tvweek.com/news/2008/01/fox_wont_sell_super_bowl_ads_t.php Fox Won't Sell Super Bowl Ads to Candidates] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111144932/http://www.tvweek.com/news/2008/01/fox_wont_sell_super_bowl_ads_t.php |date=January 11, 2012 }}. ''[[TV Week]]''. January 24, 2008.</ref> while the NFL forbids ads for gambling, hard liquor, and banned substances from airing during any of its telecasts.<ref name="wsj-nflbannedcompany"/><ref name="usatoday-gncban"/><ref name="wsj-liquorads">{{cite web|title=NFL Adds Liquor to Menu of Advertisers|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/nfl-adds-liquor-to-menu-of-advertisers-1496441710|website=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=3 June 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170620054841/https://www.wsj.com/articles/nfl-adds-liquor-to-menu-of-advertisers-1496441710|archive-date=June 20, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}{{subscription required}}</ref>
=== Just For Feet: "Kenyan Mission" === At [[Super Bowl XXXIII]], footwear retailer [[Just For Feet]] aired its first Super Bowl ad. In the commercial, a barefoot [[Kenya]]n runner is tracked by a group of Caucasian men in a [[Humvee]]. The runner is offered drug-laced water which knocks him unconscious; when he wakes up, the runner discovers that the men had given him [[Nike Inc.|Nike]] shoes. The runner rejects the shoes and attempts to shake them off whilst running away.<ref name="salon-adfromhell"/>
The ad was widely criticized for its derogatory premise; [[Bob Garfield]] described the commercial as being "[[Neocolonialism|neo-colonialist]]", "culturally [[Imperialism|imperialist]]", and "probably [[racist]]", while Chuck McBride, creative director of Nike's agency [[Wieden+Kennedy]], stated that he "couldn't believe that they had done this." Just For Feet had spent $7 million on the ad, including $1.7 million for the time, and the rest on production and promotional costs. Despite its concerns about its content, Just For Feet relied on the expertise of their hired agency, [[Saatchi & Saatchi]], because they assured that the ad was their best work. Just For Feet CEO Harold Ruttenberg explained to ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]'' that "we took out advertisements. We gave away more than $1 million of product. Then the ad runs. And you would not believe the deluge of comments made about this company. I couldn't sleep for a solid month. And it's all because of these guys who said they knew everything."<ref name="salon-adfromhell"/>
Just For Feet filed a $10 million lawsuit against Saatchi & Saatchi for [[malpractice]], alleging that the agency was damaging its reputation and goodwill through its "appallingly unacceptable and shockingly unprofessional performance", which ran "contrary to the deepest held principles of Just for Feet, which has always sought to promote racial harmony, finds racism abhorrent, and condemns drug use." Just for Feet filed for [[chapter 11 bankruptcy]] in November 1999, and the lawsuit was dropped. It was later found that the company had been engaging in [[accounting fraud]].<ref name="salon-adfromhell">{{Cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/1999/05/28/kenya/|title=The ad from hell|date=1999-05-28|work=Salon|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207122817/https://www.salon.com/1999/05/28/kenya/|archive-date=February 7, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/advertising/2006-02-03-super-ads-usat_x.htm|title=Ten rules to make ads magical|website=USA Today|access-date=2018-02-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170807170107/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/advertising/2006-02-03-super-ads-usat_x.htm|archive-date=August 7, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/birmingham/stories/2000/04/03/focus4.html|title=Just For Feet: The rise and fall of a superstar|website=www.bizjournals.com|access-date=2018-02-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170302112100/http://www.bizjournals.com/birmingham/stories/2000/04/03/focus4.html|archive-date=March 2, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB105278122330015100|title=Former Official at Just for Feet Pleads Guilty to Fraud Charges|last=|first=|date=|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-02-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180102214014/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB105278122330015100|archive-date=2018-01-02|dead-url=yes|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== General Motors: "Robot" === At [[Super Bowl XLI]], [[General Motors]] aired a 60-second ad entitled "Robot", which was meant to promote the powertrain warranty it offered for its vehicles. Themed around an "obsession" with quality, the ad depicted an assembly line robot being fired for dropping a screw. After attempting several alternative careers, the robot is depicted committing [[suicide]] by rolling off the edge of a bridge into a river. The sequence is interrupted to reveal that the events were just a dream, and that the robot had not been fired at all. Although ranking in ninth place on the Adbowl survey, "Robot" received criticism for its glamorization of suicide; the [[American Foundation for Suicide Prevention]] (AFSP) was a notable critic of the spot, as well as the [[National Alliance on Mental Illness]] (NAMI) and other suicide prevention groups. The AFSP stated that "the ad, in its carelessness, portrays suicide as a viable option when someone fails or loses their job."<ref name="adage-gmrobot">{{cite web|title=GM to Edit Super Bowl Suicidal Robot Spot|url=http://adage.com/article/news/gm-edit-super-bowl-suicidal-robot-spot/114888/|website=Advertising Age|accessdate=January 31, 2016|date=February 9, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160206185853/http://adage.com/article/news/gm-edit-super-bowl-suicidal-robot-spot/114888/|archive-date=February 6, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="cnnmoney-gmrobor">{{cite web|title=GM changing robot suicide ad|url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/02/09/news/companies/gm_robotad/|website=CNNMoney.com|accessdate=January 31, 2016|date=February 9, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160207140038/http://money.cnn.com/2007/02/09/news/companies/gm_robotad/|archive-date=February 7, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Some critics also interpreted the ad's thematics as being in poor taste, as GM had laid off 35,000 factory workers in the previous year.<ref name="cnnmoney-gmrobor"/><ref name="mpp">{{cite web|title=GM's Wild Ride Of A Week Results In Robot Ad Revision|url=http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/55335/gms-wild-ride-of-a-week-results-in-robot-ad-revis.html?edition=|publisher=MediaPost Publications|accessdate=January 31, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003054230/http://www.mediapost.com/publications/article/55335/gms-wild-ride-of-a-week-results-in-robot-ad-revis.html?edition=|archive-date=October 3, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
A GM spokesperson defended the commercial as being "a story of GM's commitment to quality", and stated that this was "the predominant impression by previewers of the ad". GM pulled the original version of the ad from its YouTube page, and edited the ad to remove the suicide scene from future airings.<ref name="cnnmoney-gmrobor"/><ref name="mpp"/>
=== Focus on the Family pro-life ad === [[File:Tim Tebow Denver Sports Authority Field 2012-01-01.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Focus on the Family]] received criticism for its [[pro-life]] ad featuring [[Tim Tebow]].]] {{main|Focus on the Family#Football advertisements}} At [[Super Bowl XLIV]], the non-profit evangelical organization [[Focus on the Family]] aired an advertisement featuring then-[[Florida Gators football|Florida Gators]] [[quarterback]] [[Tim Tebow]] and his mother, Pam. Prior to becoming pregnant with Tim, and while serving as [[Baptist]] [[missionaries]] in the [[Philippines]], Pam had contracted [[amoebic dysentery]] and fell into a [[coma]]. She discovered she was pregnant while recovering. Because of the medications used to treat her, the fetus experienced a severe [[placental abruption]].<ref name="Early years"/> Doctors expected a [[stillbirth]] and recommended an [[abortion]]. The Tebows decided against it, citing their strong faith.<ref name="Early years">{{cite web|title=Coaching character|url=http://www.gainesville.com/article/20071007/NEWS/710060317?p=1&tc=pg|work=The Gainesville Sun|last=Richardson|first=Suzy A.|date=October 7, 2007|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6C3RRbZ4e?url=http://www.gainesville.com/article/20071007/NEWS/710060317?p%3D1%26tc%3Dpg|archivedate=November 9, 2012|accessdate=November 10, 2007|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In the ad, Pam described Tim as a "miracle baby" who "almost didn't make it into this world", and remarked that "with all our family's been through, we have to be tough"—after which she was tackled by Tim. The ad itself made no reference to abortion or Christianity, and directed viewers to the organization's website.<ref name=latimes-tebowhype>{{Cite web|title=Tebow ad falls short of the hype|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/feb/08/nation/la-na-tebow-abortion8-2010feb08|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=January 19, 2014|first=Robin|last=Abcarian|date=February 8, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221051659/http://articles.latimes.com/2010/feb/08/nation/la-na-tebow-abortion8-2010feb08|archive-date=February 21, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="slate-tebowad"/>
The then-unseen ad drew criticism from some women's rights groups, who asked CBS to pull the ad because they felt it would be divisive. [[Planned Parenthood]] released a video response of its own featuring fellow NFL player [[Sean James]].<ref name=nyorker-tebowdefense>{{cite web|last=Davidson|first=Amy|title=The Tebow Defense|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/closeread/2010/02/the-tebow-defense.html|work=The New Yorker|accessdate=January 19, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131007044752/http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/closeread/2010/02/the-tebow-defense.html|archive-date=October 7, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=usatoday-pptebow>{{Cite web|title=Planned Parenthood responds to Tim Tebow Super Bowl ad|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2010-02-03-planned-parenthood-tim-tebow_N.htm|work=USA Today|accessdate=January 19, 2014|first=Michael|last=McCarthy|date=February 4, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202114303/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2010-02-03-planned-parenthood-tim-tebow_N.htm|archive-date=February 2, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The claim that Tebow's family chose not to perform an abortion was also widely criticized; as [[Abortion in the Philippines|abortion is illegal in the Philippines]], critics felt that it was implausible that a doctor would recommend the procedure in the first place.<ref name="slate-tebowad">{{cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/2010/01/28/super_bowl_ad/ |work=Salon |title=The truth behind Tebow’s tale |first=Tracy |last=Clark-Flory |date=January 28, 2010 |access-date=February 2, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322161100/http://www.salon.com/2010/01/28/super_bowl_ad/ |archive-date=March 22, 2012 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |work=Huffington Post |title=Tim Tebow Super Bowl Ad May Be Based On Falsehood, Lawyer Claims |date=March 31, 2010 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/29/tim-tebow-super-bowl-ad-m_n_442808.html |first=Whitney |last=Snyder |access-date=February 2, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111228205810/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/29/tim-tebow-super-bowl-ad-m_n_442808.html |archive-date=December 28, 2011 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> CBS's decision to run the ad was also criticized for deviating from its past policy of rejecting issue and advocacy-based commercials during the Super Bowl, including those by left leaning or perceived left leaning groups such as [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]], [[MoveOn.org]] and the [[United Church of Christ]] (which wanted to run an ad that was pro-[[same-sex marriage]]). However, CBS stated that "we have for some time moderated our approach to advocacy submissions after it became apparent that our stance did not reflect public sentiment or industry norms on the issue."<ref name=latimes-cbsad>{{Cite web|title=CBS defends decision to run politically sensitive Tim Tebow ad during Super Bowl|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jan/27/business/la-fi-ct-cbs27-2010jan27|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=January 19, 2014|first=Meg|last=James|date=January 27, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110913195632/http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jan/27/business/la-fi-ct-cbs27-2010jan27|archive-date=September 13, 2011|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===Ashley Madison and ManCrunch=== [[Avid Life Media]], an operator of [[online dating service]]s, has had two Super Bowl ads rejected by broadcasters. In 2009, [[NBC]] rejected an ad for the [[extramarital]] dating site [[Ashley Madison]], which featured the tagline "Who Are You Doing After the Game?", from appearing during [[Super Bowl XLIII]].<ref name=nydailynews/> Avid Life Media's CEO [[Noel Biderman]] felt the rejection was "ridiculous", noting an apparent [[double standard]] of allowing advertisements for [[alcoholic beverage]]s to air during NFL games despite the number of [[Long-term effects of alcohol#Alcohol-related deaths|deaths]] attributed to them. Biderman considered the NFL demographic to be a core audience of the site, and promised to "find a way to let them know about the existence of this service."<ref name=nydailynews>{{Cite web| last=Hill| first=Catey| date=January 29, 2009| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2009/01/28/2009-01-28_banned_these_ads_are_too_racy_for_the_su-1.html| title=Banned! These ads are too racy for the Super Bowl| work=[[The New York Daily News]]| accessdate=January 6, 2010| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203071155/http://www.nydailynews.com/money/2009/01/28/2009-01-28_banned_these_ads_are_too_racy_for_the_su-1.html| archive-date=February 3, 2009| dead-url=no| df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The following year at [[Super Bowl XLIV]], an advertisement for Ashley Madison's sister site [[ManCrunch]]—a dating website for [[homosexual]] relationships—was rejected by [[CBS]]. The ad featured two male football fans reaching into the same bowl of chips, and after a brief pause, passionately kissing and [[dry humping]] each other, much to the surprise of another man present. Company spokesperson Elissa Buchter considered the rejection to be discrimination, by contending that CBS would not have objected to the ad had it featured a kiss between a man and a woman, and acknowledging the frequent airplay of advertisements for [[erectile dysfunction]] medications on U.S. television as a double standard. Fellow spokesperson Dominic Friesen stated that the company was "very disappointed" of CBS's decision, noting that the network had allowed the aforementioned Focus on the Family ad to air during the game.<ref name=fancast-mancrunch/><ref name=hp-mancrunch>{{Cite web|title=ManCrunch SuperBowl Ad REJECTED: Gay Dating Site Ad Denied By CBS (VIDEO)|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/28/mancrunch-superbowl-ad-ga_n_440773.html|work=Huffington Post|publisher=[[AOL]]|accessdate=February 5, 2014|first=Danny|last=Shea|date=January 28, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109235939/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/01/28/mancrunch-superbowl-ad-ga_n_440773.html|archive-date=January 9, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A ''[[New York Post]]'' writer felt that their ad was "no more racy than nearly any beer commercial not starring the Budweiser Clydesdales".<ref name=nyp-mancrunch>{{Cite web|title=Man-kiss ad isn't gay-OK with CBS|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/all_guy_dating_site_gets_super_bowl_fCCRuiVFPXkWlORm7cs03N|publisher=The New York Post|accessdate=February 2, 2013|first=Amanda|last=Melillo|date=January 29, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120416000859/http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/all_guy_dating_site_gets_super_bowl_fCCRuiVFPXkWlORm7cs03N|archive-date=April 16, 2012|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Avid Life was also accused of [[ambush marketing]] by critics, who argued that the company was intentionally submitting ads that would get rejected by broadcasters and receive free publicity from the ensuing controversy, thus removing the need to actually buy ad time during the game. However, the company denied these claims, and indicated that it did have serious intentions to purchase ad time during the game if its commercials were accepted.<ref name=fancast-mancrunch>{{cite web|last=Phillips|first=Tracy|title=CBS Rejects Gay Dating Site’s Super Bowl Ad|url=http://www.fancast.com/blogs/2010/tv-news/cbs-rejects-gay-themed-super-bowl-ad/|work=Fancast.com|accessdate=February 5, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310131813/http://www.fancast.com/blogs/2010/tv-news/cbs-rejects-gay-themed-super-bowl-ad|archivedate=March 10, 2011}}</ref><ref name=hp-mancrunch/> In an article posted following the 2015 security breach of Ashley Madison, a former CBS standards & practices employee stated that the ManCrunch ad had actually been rejected for its use of NFL trademarks, and not because of its content.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Bartlett|first1=Kristen|title=How Ashley Madison ruined my reputation (on purpose) long before the hack.|url=http://happyplace.someecards.com/workplace/ashley-madison-avid-life-media-super-bowl-homophobic-ad/|accessdate=July 22, 2015|publisher=[[Someecards]]|date=July 21, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150722134807/http://happyplace.someecards.com/workplace/ashley-madison-avid-life-media-super-bowl-homophobic-ad/|archive-date=July 22, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
===PETA=== [[Animal rights]] activist organization [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]], known for its salacious and shocking [[publicity stunt]]s, has routinely submitted Super Bowl ads that have been rejected. Most of the advertisements have been explicitly sexual in nature. In 2018, PETA submitted a [[blasphemy|blasphemous]] advertisement instead, with a priest (portrayed by [[James Cromwell]]) telling a meat industry executive that he could not be forgiven for the sins of what PETA claimed were deceptive advertisements, even if he confessed. NBC expressed willingness to air the 2018 advertisement on the condition that the organization would buy additional ads during the [[2018 Winter Olympics]], which would have doubled the price; PETA refused and accused the network of [[price gouging]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a15886361/peta-super-bowl-ad-james-cromwell/|title=PETA Just Released an Incredibly Controversial "Super Bowl" Ad|first=Megan|last=Friedman|work=Country Living|date=January 25, 2018|accessdate=January 28, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180129005022/http://www.countryliving.com/life/entertainment/a15886361/peta-super-bowl-ad-james-cromwell/|archive-date=January 29, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== Randall Terry anti-abortion ad === In 2012, [[Randall Terry]] attempted to use a provision in [[Federal Communications Commission]] policies requiring "reasonable access" to local [[political advertising|advertising time for political candidates]] within 45 days of an election or primary, to force several [[NBC]] stations to air a graphic [[anti-abortion]] [[attack ad]] during [[Super Bowl XLVI]] that featured images of blood-covered [[fetus]]es. Following a complaint by the Chicago-based [[NBC Owned Television Stations|NBC-owned]] station [[WMAQ-TV|WMAQ]], the FCC ruled that Terry could not expect reasonable access to advertising time during the Super Bowl because of the magnitude of the event and the limited amount of local advertising time available. Furthermore, it was also found that Terry did not show enough evidence that he was a ''bona fide'' candidate eligible to receive ad time in the first place.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0212/72430.html |title=FCC Can Nix Super Bowl Ad |work=Politico |date=February 3, 2012 |accessdate=February 3, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204123217/http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0212/72430.html |archive-date=February 4, 2012 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=guardian-fetus>{{Cite web|title=Randall Terry's self-promoting Super Bowl fetus ads|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2012/jan/12/randall-terry-super-bowl-fetus-ads|work=The Guardian|accessdate=February 2, 2013|location=London|first=Amanda|last=Marcotte|date=January 12, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227101916/http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2012/jan/12/randall-terry-super-bowl-fetus-ads|archive-date=December 27, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== Chrysler: "Halftime in America" === {{main|Halftime in America}} Chrysler's [[Super Bowl XLVI]] ad "Halftime in America" was controversial due to its political overtones, especially as it came during the lead-up to the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 U.S. presidential election]]. Critics interpreted the ad as being in support of re-electing [[Barack Obama]], suggesting that the metaphor of "[[halftime]] in America" symbolized the performance of Obama's first four-year term as president going into his re-election campaign, and noting Obama had supported [[George W. Bush]]'s bailout of Chrysler whilst acting as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] senator.<ref name=newyorker-bushbailout>{{cite web|last1=Cassidy|first1=John|title=An Inconvenient Truth: It Was George W. Bush Who Bailed Out the Automakers|url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/john-cassidy/an-inconvenient-truth-it-was-george-w-bush-who-bailed-out-the-automakers|accessdate=March 25, 2015|work=The New Yorker|date=March 16, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402091111/http://www.newyorker.com/news/john-cassidy/an-inconvenient-truth-it-was-george-w-bush-who-bailed-out-the-automakers|archive-date=April 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> It was also noted that Eastwood had made statements against the bailouts in 2011, had stated that he "couldn’t recall ever voting for a Democratic presidential candidate", and that he was a supporter of Republican candidate [[John McCain]] during the 2008 campaign. Eastwood would later appear as a surprise guest at the [[2012 Republican National Convention]] in support of nominee [[Mitt Romney]], [[Clint Eastwood at the 2012 Republican National Convention|addressing an empty chair meant to represent Obama]].<ref name=time-halftimeinamerica/><ref name="BarbaroShear">{{Cite web|last1=Barbaro|first1=Michael|last2=Shear|first2=Michael D.|title=Before Talk With a Chair, Clearance From the Top|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/01/us/politics/romney-aides-scratch-their-heads-over-eastwoods-speech.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=August 31, 2012|date=August 31, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120901022917/http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/01/us/politics/romney-aides-scratch-their-heads-over-eastwoods-speech.html|archive-date=September 1, 2012|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=nyt-chrysler2012>{{Cite web |last1=Blow |first1=Charles M. |title=It’s Halftime in America |url=http://campaignstops.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/02/06/its-halftime-in-america/?_r=0 |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 6, 2012 |access-date=March 25, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402164457/http://campaignstops.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/02/06/its-halftime-in-america/?_r=0 |archive-date=April 2, 2015 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===SodaStream=== In 2013, [[SodaStream]] submitted a Super Bowl advertisement directed by [[Alex Bogusky]], which featured a pair of [[Coca-Cola]] and [[Pepsi]] deliverymen finding their bottles exploding and disappearing when another person uses the SodaStream to make their own beverages; representing a [[Disruptive innovation|disruption]] of the [[soft drink]] market. The ad was rejected by [[CBS]] for its direct attacks towards the two rival companies.<ref name=dailybeast-soda>{{cite web|title=How SodaStream Took on the Super Bowl—and Lost, Then Won|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/02/01/how-sodastream-took-on-the-super-bowl-and-lost-then-won.html|work=The Daily Beast|accessdate=February 3, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203020441/http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/02/01/how-sodastream-took-on-the-super-bowl-and-lost-then-won.html|archive-date=February 3, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A ''[[Forbes]]'' writer expressed concern that the network may have had intentionally shown [[protectionism]] towards the two soft drink companies (who have been long-time Super Bowl advertisers), and drew comparisons to a recent incident where the [[CBS Interactive|CBS-owned]] technology news site [[CNET]] was controversially forced by its parent company to block [[Dish Network]]'s [[Hopper (DVR)|Hopper with Sling]] [[digital video recorder]] from being considered Best in Show at [[International CES|CES 2013]] because the broadcaster was in active litigation over an automatic [[commercial skipping]] feature on the device.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Burns|first=Will|title=CBS Bans SodaStream Ad. Where's The Outrage?|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/willburns/2013/01/31/cbs-bans-sodastream-ad-wheres-the-outrage/|accessdate=February 1, 2013|magazine=Forbes|date=January 31, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203012929/http://www.forbes.com/sites/willburns/2013/01/31/cbs-bans-sodastream-ad-wheres-the-outrage/|archive-date=February 3, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Horovitz|first=Bruce|title=Ad legend bashes Coke, Pepsi in Super Bowl return|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/01/15/soda-stream-super-bowl-commercial-alex-bogusky/1836061/|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=January 15, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130124154826/http://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2013/01/15/soda-stream-super-bowl-commercial-alex-bogusky/1836061/|archive-date=January 24, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Stampler|first=Laura|title=That Awesome Banned SodaStream Commercial Is Going To Be A Super Bowl Ad|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/banned-sodastream-ad-to-air-during-super-bowl-2012-12|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=[[Business Insider]]|date=December 4, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130125083800/http://www.businessinsider.com/banned-sodastream-ad-to-air-during-super-bowl-2012-12|archive-date=January 25, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
An older SodaStream commercial was shown in its place, which also featured exploding pop bottles in a similar fashion, but with no direct references to any other brand;<ref name=dailybeast-soda/> ironically, this particular ad had been banned in the United Kingdom by [[Clearcast]] for being considered "a denigration of the bottled drinks market."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Sweney|first=Mark|title=SodaStream to seek legal advice after ad ban appeal fails|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/dec/04/sodastream-fails-ad-ban|accessdate=January 25, 2013|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=December 4, 2012|location=London|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203181610/http://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/dec/04/sodastream-fails-ad-ban|archive-date=February 3, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Another SodaStream ad featuring [[Scarlett Johansson]] was produced for and aired during [[Super Bowl XLVIII]] in 2014; the supposed rejection of an initial version for containing the line "Sorry, Coke and Pepsi" was overshadowed by growing controversies around the company's use of a factory that was [[International law and Israeli settlements|located in]] an [[Israeli settlement]] on the [[West Bank]].<ref name=guardian-sodastream14>{{cite web|title=Scarlett Johansson's Super Bowl ad gets extra fizz from TV ban|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jan/28/scarlett-johansson-super-bowl-ad-sodastream-tv-ban|work=The Guardian|accessdate=February 6, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140131075357/http://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jan/28/scarlett-johansson-super-bowl-ad-sodastream-tv-ban|archive-date=January 31, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=nyt-sodastream14>{{Cite web |title=Both Sides Declare P.R. Victory in Skirmish Over SodaStream Super Bowl Ad |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/02/03/both-sides-declare-p-r-victory-in-skirmish-over-sodastream-super-bowl-ad |work=[[NYTimes.com]] |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] |first=Robert |last=Mackey |date=February 3, 2014 |access-date=February 6, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203195815/http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/02/03/both-sides-declare-p-r-victory-in-skirmish-over-sodastream-super-bowl-ad/ |archive-date=February 3, 2014 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
=== Coca-Cola: "It's Beautiful" === In 2014, [[Coca-Cola]] aired a Super Bowl advertisement entitled "It's Beautiful"; themed around [[multiculturalism]], the ad featured scenes depicting [[Race and ethnicity in the United States|Americans of various ethnicities]], along with a [[same-sex couple]]—the first to ever appear in a Super Bowl ad, set to a rendition of the [[American patriotic music|patriotic]] hymn "[[America The Beautiful]]" with lyrics sung in multiple languages.<ref name=time-cocacolaad/><ref name=guardian-cocacolaad/>
The ad was divisive, with users taking to [[Twitter]] under the [[hashtag]] "#SpeakAmerican" to discuss their views and opinions on its content: those against the ad argued that per the [[melting pot]] principle, Coca-Cola should not have used languages other than [[English language|English]], the [[Languages of the United States|most common language of the country]], to promote its products to ethnic minorities, and former [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Congressman]] [[Allen West (politician)|Allen West]] stated that "If we cannot be proud enough as a country to sing 'America the Beautiful' in English in a commercial during the Super Bowl, by a company as American as they come—doggone we are on the road to perdition." By contrast, others praised the ad for celebrating the diversity of American people. ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' writer [[Jill Filipovic]] noted that the company had been increasingly targeting minorities, such as [[Latino American]]s (who are more likely to be heavy drinkers of soft drinks because of their low cost) and drew comparisons to the marketing of [[cigarettes]] to women, but that "before we applaud Coke's advertising diversity, we should ask: do we really want Coke to diversify?"<ref name="time-cocacolaad"/><ref name=independent-cocacolaad>{{Cite web|title=A racist response? Coca-Cola's multicultural Super Bowl ad infuriates Twitter users|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/a-racist-response-cocacolas-multicultural-super-bowl-ad-infuriates-twitter-users-9103853.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=February 4, 2014|location=London|first=Antonia|last=Molloy|date=February 3, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203231127/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/a-racist-response-cocacolas-multicultural-super-bowl-ad-infuriates-twitter-users-9103853.html|archive-date=February 3, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=guardian-cocacolaad>{{cite web|title=Coca-Cola's America Is Beautiful ad: why liberals should be upset|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/feb/03/coca-cola-america-is-beautiful-ad|work=The Guardian|accessdate=February 4, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140204063438/http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/feb/03/coca-cola-america-is-beautiful-ad|archive-date=February 4, 2014|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The commercial was re-aired prior to kickoff at [[Super Bowl LI]], eliciting similar criticism.<ref name="sbnation-cocacolaagain">{{cite web|title=Coca-Cola ran a Super Bowl commercial about diversity and inclusion and people are mad|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2017/2/5/14517202/coca-cola-america-the-beautiful-add-boycott-twitter|website=SB Nation|accessdate=6 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206031556/http://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2017/2/5/14517202/coca-cola-america-the-beautiful-add-boycott-twitter|archive-date=February 6, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== Nationwide Insurance: "Boy" === At [[Super Bowl XLIX]] in 2015, after an eight-year hiatus, [[Nationwide Insurance]] returned to the game with two new advertisements. The second of these advertisements, "Boy" (also commonly referred to as "Make Safe Happen"),<ref name=cbj-xlixrecap>{{Cite web|title=Super Bowl ads recap: Nationwide and Budweiser had people buzzing, for better or worse|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/columbus/blog/2015/02/super-bowl-ads-recap-nationwide-and-budweiser-had.html|website=Columbus Business First|accessdate=March 13, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402170703/http://www.bizjournals.com/columbus/blog/2015/02/super-bowl-ads-recap-nationwide-and-budweiser-had.html|archive-date=April 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> featured a child explaining that he couldn't grow up because he had already died—followed by scenes of an overflowing bathtub (implying drowning), spilled cleaning products (implying poisoning), and a television having fallen off of a wall. The ad was intended to promote Nationwide's child protection campaign ''Make Safe Happen''; operated in partnership with [[Safe Kids USA]] and [[Nationwide Children's Hospital]], it aims to draw awareness to deaths caused by preventable household accidents.<ref name=fastco-makesafehappen>{{cite web|title=Nationwide wants you to get serious about kid safety|url=http://www.fastcocreate.com/3041239/nationwide-wants-you-to-get-serious-about-kid-safety|website=Fast Company|accessdate=March 13, 2015}}</ref><ref name=slate-depressing>{{cite web |last1=Griswold |first1=Allison |title=What’s With All the Dark, Depressing Super Bowl Ads This Year? |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/moneybox/2015/02/01/super_bowl_xlix_ads_nationwide_nissan_run_grim_serious_commercials.html |website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |publisher=[[The Slate Group]] |date=February 1, 2015 |access-date=February 7, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150207063228/http://www.slate.com/blogs/moneybox/2015/02/01/super_bowl_xlix_ads_nationwide_nissan_run_grim_serious_commercials.html |archive-date=February 7, 2015 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=fastco-makesafehappenad>{{cite web|title=Nationwide's Child Safety Awareness Ad Was Supposed To Harsh Your Super Bowl Buzz|url=http://www.fastcocreate.com/3041249/super-bowl-xlix/nationwides-child-safety-awareness-ad-was-supposed-to-harsh-your-super-bowl-|website=Fast Company|accessdate=March 13, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150304181740/http://www.fastcocreate.com/3041249/super-bowl-xlix/nationwides-child-safety-awareness-ad-was-supposed-to-harsh-your-super-bowl-|archive-date=March 4, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Viewers and critics acknowledged that the subject matter of "Boy" was a major contrast to other, upbeat and comedic ads broadcast during Super Bowl XLIX (including Nationwide's second ad, "Invisible Mindy"). Reception towards the ad was overwhelmingly negative; viewers criticized the company via social media for its decision to broadcast an ad dealing with such subject matter during the Super Bowl, [[Amobee]] estimated only 12% of reactions to the ad on [[Twitter]] were positive, and it ranked near the bottom of the ''USA Today'' Ad Meter results. Nationwide CMO Matthew Jauchius defended the ad, noting that the negative response was "a little stronger than we anticipated", and that "Boy" was intended to "begin a dialogue to make safe happen for children everywhere."<ref name=wsj-makesafehappen>{{Cite web|title=Nationwide Knew Super Bowl Spot Would Touch a Nerve|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/cmo/2015/02/02/nationwide-knew-super-bowl-spot-would-touch-a-nerve/|website=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=March 13, 2015|first=Nathalie|last=Tadena|date=February 2, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150319091900/http://blogs.wsj.com/cmo/2015/02/02/nationwide-knew-super-bowl-spot-would-touch-a-nerve/|archive-date=March 19, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=cbf-nationwide>{{Cite web|title=Nationwide defends Super Bowl ad|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/columbus/blog/2015/02/nationwide-defends-that-super-bowl-ad.html|website=Columbus Business First|accessdate=March 13, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150311111150/http://www.bizjournals.com/columbus/blog/2015/02/nationwide-defends-that-super-bowl-ad.html|archive-date=March 11, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=nydn-makesafehappen>{{Cite web|title=Nationwide's Super Bowl XLIX ad proves to be super bummer on social media|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/nationwide-super-bowl-ad-twitter-reaction-article-1.2099796|website=New York Daily News|accessdate=March 13, 2015|date=February 2, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220004627/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/nationwide-super-bowl-ad-twitter-reaction-article-1.2099796|archive-date=February 20, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Jauchius later exited Nationwide two months after the advertisement aired.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://adage.com/article/cmo-strategy/nationwide-cmo-departs-wake-dead-buy-super-bowl-ad/298485/|title=Nationwide CMO Exits in Wake of 'Dead Boy' Super Bowl Ad|access-date=2017-08-10|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170807165959/http://adage.com/article/cmo-strategy/nationwide-cmo-departs-wake-dead-buy-super-bowl-ad/298485/|archive-date=August 7, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== 84 Lumber: "The Journey" === Building supply company [[84 Lumber]] debuted at [[Super Bowl LI]] with "The Journey"; the ad depicted a mother and daughter migrating from [[Mexico]] to the United States border, only to discover that a [[border wall|wall]] had been built on it. However, after the daughter presented a handmade version of the U.S. flag that she had made with pieces of fabric collected along the way, the two discover a giant door in the wall. The ending of the ad is accompanied by the tagline "The will to succeed is always welcome here."<ref name="time-84">{{cite web|title=Watch the 84 Lumber Super Bowl Ad Everyone Is Talking About|url=http://time.com/4660707/super-bowl-84-lumber-ad/|website=Time|accessdate=6 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206234237/http://time.com/4660707/super-bowl-84-lumber-ad/|archive-date=February 6, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="vf-84">{{cite web|title=Watch the End of the Super Bowl Lumber Commercial too Controversial to Air|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/02/lumber-commercial-ending-super-bowl-controversial|website=Vanity Fair|accessdate=6 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170207162306/http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2017/02/lumber-commercial-ending-super-bowl-controversial|archive-date=February 7, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="wsj-84lumberfull">{{cite web|title=84 Lumber Super Bowl Campaign Shows Border Wall With a Big Door|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/84-lumber-super-bowl-campaign-shows-border-wall-with-a-big-door-1486343484|website=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=6 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170206191852/https://www.wsj.com/articles/84-lumber-super-bowl-campaign-shows-border-wall-with-a-big-door-1486343484|archive-date=February 6, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The original version of the ad was rejected by Fox, as they believed that the border wall imagery was too politically sensitive in the wake of [[Donald Trump]]'s presidency, as his campaign promises included a plan to [[Mexico–United States barrier#Trump administration|build a wall across the entire southern border]]. The company's agency stated that it intended to present an edited version of the ad during the game, and promote the full, nearly 6-minute ad, streaming on 84 Lumber's website.<ref name="time-84"/><ref name="adage-84lumber">{{cite web|title=Fox Rejects Super Bowl Ad That Depicts a Giant Border Wall|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/construction-company-84-lumber-nixed-border-wall-super-bowl-spot/307534/|website=Advertising Age|accessdate=31 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201234252/http://adage.com/article/special-report-super-bowl/construction-company-84-lumber-nixed-border-wall-super-bowl-spot/307534/|archive-date=February 1, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="ppg-84lumber">{{cite web|title=84 Lumber goes back to drawing board to redo Super Bowl ad after Fox Sports rejection|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/business/pittsburgh-company-news/2017/01/19/84-Lumber-goes-back-to-drawing-board-to-redo-Super-Bowl-ad-after-Fox-Sports-rejection/stories/201701190067|website=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|accessdate=31 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170126173751/http://www.post-gazette.com/business/pittsburgh-company-news/2017/01/19/84-Lumber-goes-back-to-drawing-board-to-redo-Super-Bowl-ad-after-Fox-Sports-rejection/stories/201701190067|archive-date=January 26, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="adweek-thewall">{{cite web|title=84 Lumber Explores Other Options After Fox Rejects Its ‘Political’ Super Bowl Ad|url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/84-lumber-explores-other-options-after-fox-rejects-its-political-super-bowl-ad-175603/|website=Adweek|accessdate=31 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170208185938/http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/84-lumber-explores-other-options-after-fox-rejects-its-political-super-bowl-ad-175603/|archive-date=February 8, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The company reported that its website received a total of over 6 million visits in the hour following the airing, and received over 300,000 [[HTTP request|requests]] in a minute after the ad aired, causing it to crash.<ref name="time-84"/>
=== GNC: "Courage to Change" === On January 31, 2017, it was reported that an advertisement for the health store chain [[GNC (store)|GNC]] had been rejected by the NFL for broadcast during Super Bowl LI. The ad had been rejected due to the company's inclusion on a list of "[[blacklist|prohibited companies]]" issued by the [[NFL Players Association]]; a small number of GNC's products contain [[Dehydroepiandrosterone|DHEA]] and [[Synephrine]], which are [[Steroid use in American football|performance-enhancing substances banned by the NFL]]. Inclusion on this list prohibits NFL players from promoting or endorsing the company. NFL policies do not allow advertising for “dietary or nutritional supplements that contain ingredients other than vitamins and minerals, energy drinks, or any prohibited substance”. Advertisements for health stores are not banned, provided that they do not reference such products. GNC's advertisement featured motivational themes as part of a larger "Courage to Change" marketing campaign, and did not make any references to specific products sold by the chain.<ref name="usatoday-gnclawsuit">{{cite web|title=GNC's Super Bowl ad controversy escalates|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/super/2017/02/03/gnc-super-bowl-commercial-controversy-fox/97436046/|website=USA Today|accessdate=3 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170208002908/http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/super/2017/02/03/gnc-super-bowl-commercial-controversy-fox/97436046/|archive-date=February 8, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="wsj-nflbannedcompany">{{cite web|title=GNC’s Super Bowl Ad Rejected by NFL|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/gncs-super-bowl-ad-rejected-by-nfl-1485886063|website=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=1 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170201152053/https://www.wsj.com/articles/gncs-super-bowl-ad-rejected-by-nfl-1485886063|archive-date=February 1, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="usatoday-gncban">{{cite web|title=Watch the GNC ad the NFL rejected from Super Bowl|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ad-meter/2017/01/31/gnc-ad-commercial-super-bowl-rejected/97275868/|website=USA Today|accessdate=1 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170223155317/http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/ad-meter/2017/01/31/gnc-ad-commercial-super-bowl-rejected/97275868/|archive-date=February 23, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
On February 2, 2017, it was reported that GNC had threatened to sue Fox over the rejection. The letter of intent stated that the contents of GNC's commercial had been "expressly approved" twice by Fox, and that the broadcaster did not inform GNC that ads broadcast during the Super Bowl were subject to approval by the NFL or any league policies. The company stated that Fox had "induced GNC to spend millions of dollars in production costs and in the development of a national, coordinated marketing and rebranding campaign centered around this advertisement."<ref name="adage-gnclawsuit">{{cite web|title=GNC Intends to Sue Fox Over Rejected Super Bowl Spot|url=http://adage.com/article/agency-news/gnc-intends-sue-fox-rejected-super-bowl-spot/307829/|website=Advertising Age|accessdate=3 February 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170203140934/http://adage.com/article/agency-news/gnc-intends-sue-fox-rejected-super-bowl-spot/307829/|archive-date=February 3, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="usatoday-gnclawsuit"/>
=== Ram Trucks: "Built to Serve" === In 2018 at [[Super Bowl LII]], Fiat Chrysler Automobiles marque [[Ram Trucks]] aired a commercial entitled "Built to Serve", as one of two Ram ads during the game. It featured an extract from the "Drum Major Instinct" sermon given by [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] on February 4, 1968 (exactly 50 years prior), wherein King explained the virtues of serving others. The speech was, in turn, set to footage of people using their Ram vehicles to help others.<ref name="nyt-mlkad"/><ref name="adweek-mlkad"/>
The ad was largely criticized, as viewers considered it to be in bad taste for FCA to use the words of MLK to promote a product. It was also pointed out that, ironically, King had made comments criticizing the advertising industry during the same sermon. He described advertisers as being "gentlemen of massive verbal persuasion", explaining that "in order to be a man of distinction, you must drink this whiskey. In order to make your neighbors envious, you must drive this type of car. In order to be lovely to love you must wear this kind of lipstick or this kind of perfume. And you know, before you know it, you're just buying that stuff." William B. Wachtel, co-founder of the [[Drum Major Institute]], stated that "In a twist of irony, one of the specific evils Dr. King condemned was the exploitation of the drum major instinct by advertisers, particularly car advertisers".<ref name="usatoday-mlkad">{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/02/05/mlk-speech-used-rams-car-ad-goes-criticize-car-ads/306984002/|title=That Martin Luther King Jr. speech used in Ram's car ad? It goes on to criticize car ads.|work=USA Today|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180206133042/https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/02/05/mlk-speech-used-rams-car-ad-goes-criticize-car-ads/306984002/|archive-date=February 6, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="nyt-mlkad">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/05/business/media/mlk-commercial-ram-dodge.html|title=Ram Trucks Commercial With Martin Luther King Jr. Sermon Is Criticized|last=Maheshwari|first=Sapna|date=2018-02-05|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180220221701/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/05/business/media/mlk-commercial-ram-dodge.html|archive-date=February 20, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="adweek-mlkad"/> ''[[Current Affairs (magazine)|Current Affairs]]'' posted an edited version of the commercial on [[YouTube]], overdubbed with this section of the speech.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mediaite.com/tv/a-remixed-version-of-rams-super-bowl-ad-shows-mlk-slamming-car-commercials/|title=Someone Dubbed The Dodge Super Bowl Commercial With MLK’s Actual Thoughts on Car Ads|website=Mediaite|language=en|access-date=2018-02-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207010420/https://www.mediaite.com/tv/a-remixed-version-of-rams-super-bowl-ad-shows-mlk-slamming-car-commercials/|archive-date=February 7, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20180205/14355439159/tarnishing-history-martin-luther-king-jr-copyright-enforcement-edition.shtml|title=Tarnishing The History Of Martin Luther King Jr.: Copyright Enforcement Edition|work=Techdirt|access-date=2018-02-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207010921/https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20180205/14355439159/tarnishing-history-martin-luther-king-jr-copyright-enforcement-edition.shtml|archive-date=February 7, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Use of the speech was approved by [[Intellectual Properties Management]], the exclusive commercial licensor of King's estate. A representative of the organization stated that they approved the ad because its overall message "embodied Dr. King's philosophy that true greatness is achieved by serving others."<ref name="adweek-mlkad">{{Cite news|url=http://www.adweek.com/creativity/ram-gets-emotional-and-comical-in-a-pair-of-60-second-super-bowl-spots/|title=Ram Gets Emotional and Comical in a Pair of 60-Second Super Bowl Spots|work=Adweek|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180206131844/http://www.adweek.com/creativity/ram-gets-emotional-and-comical-in-a-pair-of-60-second-super-bowl-spots/|archive-date=February 6, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/ram-trucks-martin-luther-king-advertising-super-bowl-1202687940/|title=Commercial Crash: Ram Trucks Ad With Martin Luther King Fails to Inspire|last=Steinberg|first=Brian|date=2018-02-05|work=Variety|access-date=2018-02-06|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208131747/http://variety.com/2018/tv/news/ram-trucks-martin-luther-king-advertising-super-bowl-1202687940/|archive-date=February 8, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="usatoday-mlkad"/><ref name="nyt-mlkad"/> Although the [[King Center for Nonviolent Social Change|King Center]] distanced itself from the ad by stating that it was not responsible for its licensing, it was pointed out that Intellectual Properties Management was based within the facilities of the King Center to begin with, and thus had close ties to the family. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' columnist [[Michael Hiltzik]] argued that King's rights should be managed by a larger group of historians and scholars through an "open and transparent" process, rather than just his close family, "so at least we don't have a situation where some corporation drapes itself in King's preacherly robes while the estate issues fatuous excuses that a TV commercial embodies 'Dr. King's philosophy'."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/hiltzik/la-fi-hiltzik-dodge-martin-luther-king-20180205-story.html|title=That Ram Trucks Super Bowl ad shows it's time to loosen the King family's grip on MLK's legacy|last=Hiltzik|first=Michael|website=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2018-02-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180206113915/http://www.latimes.com/business/hiltzik/la-fi-hiltzik-dodge-martin-luther-king-20180205-story.html|archive-date=February 6, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=":0" />
== Internationally == The Super Bowl commercials are generally limited to the American television broadcast of the game. This prevents international viewers from watching the game with these often iconic commercials. Online postings of the commercials on sites such as [[YouTube]] have partially alleviated the issue,<ref name="torstar-spike"/><ref name="tgam-2012"/> while NBC posted the [[Super Bowl XLIX]] commercials on a [[Tumblr]] blog as they aired during the game for the benefit of its U.S. online stream (which did not contain all of the same ads as the television feed).<ref name=variety-superbowltumblr>{{Cite web|title=Super Bowl Ads: NBC Turns to Tumblr to Post Spots After They Air on TV|url=https://variety.com/2015/digital/news/super-bowl-ads-nbc-turns-to-tumblr-to-post-spots-after-airing-on-tv-1201410862/|website=Variety|accessdate=January 29, 2015|first=Todd|last=Spangler|date=January 21, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150129193325/http://variety.com/2015/digital/news/super-bowl-ads-nbc-turns-to-tumblr-to-post-spots-after-airing-on-tv-1201410862/|archive-date=January 29, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Complaints about the U.S. Super Bowl ads are common in Canada; although U.S. network affiliates are widely available on pay television providers in the country, "[[simultaneous substitution]]" regulations give Canadian television networks the right to request that a U.S. feed of a program be replaced with its Canadian counterpart on these providers if it is airing a program in [[simulcast]] with a U.S. network. This rule is intended to protect the investments of Canadian broadcasters in exclusive domestic broadcast rights, and also protect Canadian advertisers who had purchased their own advertising time on the Canadian network. As a result, most American Super Bowl ads are effectively "blacked out" by the Canadian broadcaster.<ref name="torstar-spike">{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/companies/article/931746--demand-for-super-bowl-ads-spikes-in-canada|title=Demand for Super Bowl ads spikes in Canada|first=Dana|last=Flavelle|work=[[Toronto Star]]|date=February 1, 2010|accessdate=February 5, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205001727/http://www.thestar.com/business/companies/article/931746--demand-for-super-bowl-ads-spikes-in-canada|archive-date=February 5, 2011|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="tgam-2012">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketing/adhocracy/why-most-super-bowl-ads-get-stopped-at-the-border/article2324816/singlepage/|title=Why most Super Bowl ads get stopped at the border|first=Susan|last=Krashinsky|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=February 3, 2011|accessdate=February 4, 2011|location=Toronto|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206050113/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketing/adhocracy/why-most-super-bowl-ads-get-stopped-at-the-border/article2324816/singlepage/|archive-date=February 6, 2012|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/business/turfed+from+simulcast/4222338/story.html|title=Funny U.S. ads turfed on CTV's Super Bowl simulcast: HD broadcast overrides Fox's on cable, replacing U.S. commercials with Canadian|first=Brendan|last=Kelly|work=[[The Gazette (Montreal)]]|date=February 4, 2010|accessdate=February 5, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110207052344/http://www.montrealgazette.com/business/turfed+from+simulcast/4222338/story.html|archive-date=February 7, 2011|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Members of Parliament [[Bob Nault]] and [[Wayne Easter]] have stated that the [[Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission]] (CRTC), Canada's telecom regulator, has only received around 100 specific complaints about Super Bowl ads in relation to the simsub rules.<ref name="torstar-complaints">{{cite web|title=Canadian MPs say CRTC made a bad call on Super Bowl ads|url=https://www.thestar.com/business/2016/12/15/canadian-mps-say-crtc-made-a-bad-call-on-super-bowl-ads.html|website=Toronto Star|accessdate=18 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118215613/https://www.thestar.com/business/2016/12/15/canadian-mps-say-crtc-made-a-bad-call-on-super-bowl-ads.html|archive-date=January 18, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Some U.S.-based advertisers, particularly [[PepsiCo]] and [[Anheuser-Busch]] (via its Canadian subsidiary [[Labatt]]), do buy ad time during the Canadian broadcast on [[CTV Television|CTV]], owned by [[Bell Media]]—the broadcasting subsidiary of Canadian telecommunications firm [[BCE]] and the current rightsholder of the game, to air at least some of their American commercials, but many Canadian advertisers simply re-air ads from their regular rotation, or air the same ad multiple times over the course of the game, neither of which is typical during the U.S. network broadcast.<ref name="tgam-2012" /> Reasons cited by Canadian advertisers for these practices include the additional talent and post-production fees that would be required to broadcast the American ads in Canada, and the perceived lower "cultural resonance" of the game for Canadian viewers as opposed to Americans.<ref name="tgam-2012" /> As such, and because Canada's population is approximately a tenth of the United States', advertising time costs a fraction of the price to air an ad on the U.S. broadcast: prices ranged between $170,000 to $200,000 for a 30-second slot on CTV's telecast of [[Super Bowl XLIX]].<ref name=gandm-bbad/><ref name=gandm-nomoresuperbowlsimsub/>
On the other hand, in the 2010s, there were a growing number of Super Bowl ads produced specifically for the Canadian broadcast: [[Hyundai]]'s Canadian subsidiary began airing its own Super Bowl ads in 2010,<ref name=marketing-hyundaigaspocalypse>{{cite web|title=Hyundai Goes Apocalyptic for Super Bowl|url=http://www.marketingmag.ca/brands/hyundai-goes-apocalyptic-on-super-bowl-broadcast-70745|website=Marketing Magazine|accessdate=February 1, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402095138/http://www.marketingmag.ca/brands/hyundai-goes-apocalyptic-on-super-bowl-broadcast-70745|archive-date=April 2, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and Budweiser produced the [[ice hockey|hockey]]-themed "Flash Fans" to air during the Canadian broadcast of [[Super Bowl XLVI]]. The following year, two Canadian companies—[[BlackBerry Limited|BlackBerry]] and [[Gildan Activewear]], made their debut as U.S. Super Bowl advertisers; their ads were also broadcast in Canada alongside those by [[McDonald's Canada]], who debuted its "Our Food. Your Questions." campaign, Budweiser's [[Internet of things|internet-connected]] hockey goal lights, and Hyundai Canada's "Gaspocalypse", promoting the [[Hyundai Sonata Hybrid|Sonata Hybrid]].<ref name=gandm-bbad>{{Cite web|title=Super Bowl to kick off cross-border ad action|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketing/super-bowl-to-kick-off-cross-border-ad-action/article8140216/|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|accessdate=February 2, 2013|location=Toronto|date=February 2, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203042005/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketing/super-bowl-to-kick-off-cross-border-ad-action/article8140216/|archive-date=February 3, 2013|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Budweiser expanded its goal light campaign for Super Bowl 50, which featured an ad introducing a {{convert|20|foot|m}}-tall goal lamp used as part of a promotional campaign leading towards the [[2016 World Cup of Hockey]].<ref name="gandm-doublesdown">{{Cite web|title=Labatt doubles down as Canadians embrace Bud Red Light program|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketing/labatt-doubles-down-as-canadians-embrace-bud-red-light-program/article28518391/|accessdate=February 3, 2016|work=The Globe and Mail|date=February 3, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203123618/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketing/labatt-doubles-down-as-canadians-embrace-bud-red-light-program/article28518391/|archive-date=February 3, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
=== Canadian simsub ban === On January 29, 2015, the CRTC announced a proposal to forbid the invocation of simultaneous substitution on the Super Bowl telecast, thus allowing U.S. feeds of the event to co-exist with those of Canadian rightsholders on pay television providers. The decision came as a result of a series of hearings held by the CRTC known as ''Let's Talk TV'', which explored reforms of the Canadian television industry: the Commission cited viewer frustration over the use of simsubs, especially surrounding the Super Bowl, and argued that the commercials were an "integral part" of the game due to their cultural significance.<ref name=gandm-nomoresuperbowlsimsub>{{Cite web|title=CRTC opens door for U.S. Super Bowl ads to air on Canadian TV|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketing/crtc-opens-door-for-us-super-bowl-ads-to-air-on-canadian-tv/article22696212/|accessdate=January 29, 2015|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=January 29, 2015|location=Toronto|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150201031352/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketing/crtc-opens-door-for-us-super-bowl-ads-to-air-on-canadian-tv/article22696212/|archive-date=February 1, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=crtc-2015-25>{{cite web|title=Broadcasting Regulatory Policy CRTC 2015-25|url=http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/archive/2015/2015-25.htm|publisher=CRTC|accessdate=February 3, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203074901/http://www.crtc.gc.ca/eng/archive/2015/2015-25.htm|archive-date=February 3, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In March 2015, Bell filed an appeal against this decision, arguing that the move would devalue its exclusive broadcast rights to the game, and violated the [[Broadcasting Act (1991)|Broadcasting Act]], which forbids the "making of regulations singling out a particular program or licensee."<ref name=gandm-bellappeal>{{Cite web|title=Bell appeals CRTC decision to air U.S. Super Bowl commercials|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bell-to-fight-crtc-ruling-on-super-bowl-simsub/article23244271/|accessdate=March 12, 2015|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|location=Toronto|date=March 2, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150309142710/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bell-to-fight-crtc-ruling-on-super-bowl-simsub/article23244271/|archive-date=March 9, 2015|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A report commissioned by Bell estimated that without this lucrative exclusivity, it would lose about US$13.6 million per-year.<ref name="bloomberg-blitzes"/>
In spite of the complaints and legal action, the CRTC issued an order on August 19, 2016 that officially implemented the new rule. On September 6, 2016, the [[Federal Court of Appeal (Canada)|Federal Court of Appeal]] dismissed Bell Media's lawsuit for being premature, because it was filed before the CRTC had formally implemented the rules.<ref name="gandm-yesnoads">{{cite web|title=Court dismisses Bell appeal of CRTC policy on Super Bowl ads|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/court-rules-against-bells-attempt-to-swap-super-bowl-commercials/article31722299/|website=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=12 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170503231636/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/court-rules-against-bells-attempt-to-swap-super-bowl-commercials/article31722299/|archive-date=May 3, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="cbc-lawsuitdismiss">{{cite web|title=Court rules against Bell in bid to overturn ban on U.S. ads airing during Super Bowl|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/crtc-super-bowl-ads-appeal-1.3751203|website=CBC News|accessdate=12 September 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160908205129/http://www.cbc.ca/news/business/crtc-super-bowl-ads-appeal-1.3751203|archive-date=September 8, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> On November 2, 2016, Bell was granted an appeal.<ref name="gandm-bellappeal 2">{{cite web|title=Bell wins right to appeal new Super Bowl ad policy|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bell-wins-right-to-appeal-new-super-bowl-ad-policy/article32643801/|website=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=2 November 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170503231633/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bell-wins-right-to-appeal-new-super-bowl-ad-policy/article32643801/|archive-date=May 3, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In the lead-up to [[Super Bowl LI]] (which would be the first game to fall under this policy), a number of stakeholders, including the NFL, Bell Media, local unions. as well as politicians from both Canada and the U.S., called upon the CRTC to reverse the ruling. U.S. senators [[Marco Rubio]] and [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)|Ron Johnson]] wrote to an ambassador that the CRTC's decision "sends a troubling signal about the value Canada places on its largest trading partner, best customer and close friend." Bell had also urged prime minister [[Justin Trudeau]] to invoke section 26(2) of the [[Broadcasting Act (1991)|Broadcasting Act]] (which grants the government power to require the broadcasting of programming that is "of urgent importance to Canadians", and had only been invoked once before to mandate the broadcast of a major speech by a Prime Minister) to override the CRTC policy and still require that the Super Bowl LI telecast be subject to simsub.<ref name="bloomberg-blitzes">{{cite web|title=NFL Blitzes Trudeau in Arcane Super Bowl Advertising Dispute|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-09/nfl-blitzes-trudeau-in-arcane-super-bowl-advertising-dispute|website=Bloomberg L.P.|accessdate=18 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118141116/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-09/nfl-blitzes-trudeau-in-arcane-super-bowl-advertising-dispute|archive-date=January 18, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Broadcasting Act|url=http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-9.01/page-5.html#docCont|publisher=Government of Canada|accessdate=18 January 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170118140027/http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/B-9.01/page-5.html#docCont#docCont|archive-date=January 18, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Court action on the CRTC ruling was not taken in time for the game, meaning that Super Bowl LI was the first to be available through Canadian television providers without being subject to simsub.<ref name="gandm-cdnratings">{{cite news|title=Bell’s Super Bowl ratings drop 39 per cent as CRTC ad policy takes effect|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bells-super-bowl-ratings-drop-39-per-cent-as-ad-policy-takes-effect/article33919635/|website=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=February 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170207022505/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bells-super-bowl-ratings-drop-39-per-cent-as-ad-policy-takes-effect/article33919635/|archive-date=February 7, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Some Canadian advertisers, such as [[Leon's]] and [[Pizza Pizza]], took advantage of the decision by purchasing local ad time from [[List of foreign television channels available in Canada|U.S. Fox affiliates carried in Canada]], to broadcast commercials aimed at the Canadian audience. The sales manager of [[Spokane]]'s affiliate [[KAYU-TV]] praised the change for helping increase demand for its limited local inventory; the station is carried on cable in the significantly larger Canadian markets of [[Calgary]] and [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]].<ref name="gandm-willfight"/>
Neither Nielsen or [[Numeris]] (Canada's main television ratings provider) calculate Canadian viewership of U.S. television channels, so it is unknown exactly how many Canadian viewers watched the game directly from Fox stations rather than CTV.<ref name="gandm-willfight"/> Following the game, it was reported that viewership of Super Bowl LI on CTV, in addition to [[CTV Two]] and [[The Sports Network|TSN]] (which simulcast the game in order to increase the saturation of Bell-owned properties carrying it, and offered an on-air sweepstakes as a publicity stunt to attract viewers), was down by 39% over Super Bowl 50.<ref name="gandm-cdnratings"/><ref name="faguy-sbli">{{cite web|last1=Faguy|first1=Steve|url=http://blog.fagstein.com/2017/01/27/ctv-super-bowl-li-plans/|title=CTV Super Bowl LI plans|date=January 27, 2017|accessdate=January 29, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202043143/http://blog.fagstein.com/2017/01/27/ctv-super-bowl-li-plans/|archive-date=February 2, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="faguy-sbli"/><ref name="gandm-paytowatch">{{cite news|title=It may pay to watch Super Bowl on Canadian TV. Literally|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketing/it-may-pay-to-watch-super-bowl-on-canadian-tv-literally/article33892725/|website=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=February 3, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170203172329/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/industry-news/marketing/it-may-pay-to-watch-super-bowl-on-canadian-tv-literally/article33892725/|archive-date=February 3, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
On December 19, 2017, the Federal Court of Appeal dismissed Bell Media's case, ruling that the CRTC's policy was reasonable.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bell-loses-appeal-of-crtcs-super-bowl-ad-ruling/article37387000/|title=Bell loses court appeal of CRTC’s Super Bowl ad ruling|work=The Globe and Mail|access-date=2017-12-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220132238/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/bell-loses-appeal-of-crtcs-super-bowl-ad-ruling/article37387000/|archive-date=December 20, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Bell Media once again filed for an appeal in January 2018, this time in the [[Supreme Court of Canada]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nationalpost.com/pmn/sports-pmn/football-sports-pmn/bell-media-and-nfl-take-appeal-over-super-bowl-ad-policy-to-supreme-court|title=Bell Media and NFL take appeal over Super Bowl ad policy to Supreme Court|date=2018-01-22|work=National Post|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
On October 1, 2018, Canada agreed to the [[United States–Mexico–Canada Agreement]]. Annex 15-D would require Canada to, in simsub regulations, "not accord [a] program treatment less favorable than the treatment accorded to other programs originating in the United States retransmitted in Canada", and specifically ordered that the CRTC policies implementing this simsub ban be rescinded.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/nafta-replacement-likely-kills-crtc-super-bowl-ad-policy-1.1145806|title=NAFTA replacement likely kills CRTC Super Bowl ad policy|date=2018-10-01|work=BNN Bloomberg|access-date=2018-10-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181002004617/https://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/nafta-replacement-likely-kills-crtc-super-bowl-ad-policy-1.1145806|archive-date=October 2, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
